149080464.review: I'm very happy with "The Last Campfire."  It's a very nice, pleasant, well-done, casual game.  Highly enjoyable.  I've got a few minor complaints about it, but they're really small and petty:  their use of first person plural pronouns instead of first person singular ones is a bit irritating.  But, since the characters are Embers and not humans and gender has absolutely nothing to do with the game, they were kind of stuck with that.  I guess they could have gone with some made up pronoun, but six of one, half a dozen of the other.  Second, even though the theme and the overall story is very nice, it has problems at the detail level.  But, it's good enough.  And finally, there are a few things that are left hanging in the game (the Cook, Orchard and giant pig come to mind).  But, again, trivial and not all that important.  Anyway, I paid just a bit over $3 for it and it took me a skosh over 10 hours to complete.  And, it's well done and enjoyable.  So, I'm completely satisfied.  Definitely recommended (though you might wait for a sale when it's under $10).

148891392.review:
In short: This game has amazing atmosphere and a fantastic art style, but the game is pretty short and the replay value is a bit lacking. If you're looking for a whimsical and emotive experience, definitely worth buying. I would recommend it regardless, but if you're looking for something more substantive, I'd recommend waiting for a sale. If you're looking to scratch an indie-game itch, this is definitely worth it.

The game is beautiful--the environments are vibrant, the soundtrack is gorgeous, and the character designs are cute and memorable. I couldn't praise the team more, they really hit it out of the park. I'm not that emotional of a person, but even I found myself moved by the end of the story and I really do think a large part of that comes from how phenomenal the presentation is.

On the other hand, the content of the game is a bit lacking. It is a puzzle game, and most of the puzzles are isolated logic/brainteaser puzzles, like block-pushing or rotation puzzles, that spring up as you try to help various strangers. There are more dynamic puzzles in the overworld, but those also tend to be fairly isolated to a single area. However, the puzzles are really hit-or-miss. I more or less breezed through most of the puzzles and the few that I couldn't figure out right away only took a few minutes of trial-and-error to get the solution right. Some of the puzzles I could hardly call puzzles, and the 1st area (which you play in the demo) does a really bad job of showing the player what puzzles they could expect. For example, there's a puzzle where you need to place a prop on a pedestal to move to the next section, send the prop down to the next level via elevator, and do that two more times. There's no thinking involved, as there's only one move you can make every time. Even if you want to say that it's for the sake of getting the player familiar with the mechanics, it's disappointing that they would have to hold your hand that tightly. That said, the puzzles do have their own narratives that progress as you complete the puzzle, so they may be thought more like cinematic setpieces, but even so, I'm sure there could have been more engaging puzzles.

If I'm not mistaken, I completed every puzzle available in the game. There are also some extra collectible notes you can find along the way and I think I got most, if not all of them on my first playthrough. At the end, my playtime was a bit shy of 5 hours after starting with the demo. And while the game was a pleasant experience, the underwhelming puzzle design holds me back from wanting to jump back in. If you're looking for that breath of fresh indie-game air, this is THE game for you, but otherwise, there's nothing wrong with waiting a little while to get it.

148884849.review: Cute, fun, and relaxing puzzle game

148881101.review: Este juego no me daba buenas vibras cuando lo conocí, dudé gracias a sus gráficos en un inicio, pero me atreví y probé la Demo, fue una muy buena experiencia la verdad, recomiendo jugarla antes de comprarlo, no será un prólogo, pero si la terminas y luego compras el juego, iniciarás donde te habías quedado, lo que no había visto antes en otros juegos. Pasando a el juego como tal, tiene muchos ámbitos buenos a destacar, como su ambientación musical, que no será muy memorable o movida, pero es muy tranquila y no peca de pretenciosa, la jugabilidad que es por lo que más destaca, el juego se trata de resolver puzzles para salvar npcs, los puzzles van subiendo su dificultad y duración mientras más avanzas en el juego, sin llegar a extremos, la paleta de color y el diseño de los personajes en un inicio puede parecer algo extraño, pero la verdad no está mal, no están sobrediseñados ni son feos a la vista. Pasando a los únicos apartados que considero algo mediocres, más no malos, del juego, están la historia, que es bastante plana, con un inicio y objetivo difusos, incluso al acabar el juego quedas con más dudas que respuestas sobre ello por lo que no es algo en lo que destaque, y por el otro lado, la extensión, es un juego en que, si eres bastante bueno resolviendo los puzzles no creo que dure más de 6 horas, cosa que le resta algunos puntos, ya que puede llegar a desilusionar si te enganchas del juego. Entonces, cual es mi recomendación? si te interesó algo de lo que dije en esta reseña, te invito a probar primero la demo del juego, es bastante extensa por si eres indeciso como yo, y es bueno, no una joya que tenga una fanbase establecida, pero si un buen título para pasar tardes en las que no tengas la más mínima idea de que hacer, y solo quieras relajarte un poco y matar tiempo.

147355006.review:
[b]The Last Campfire[/b] is a beautiful and endearing puzzle adventure that tells the story of a lost ember, trapped in a strange world, searching for a way to help fellow embers and, eventually, a way home. It is a fantastic puzzle game that will take around 7-8 hours to complete. It boasts beautiful visuals with vibrant 3D art as well as an emotive and varied soundtrack both of which accentuate and complement the gameplay perfectly. The puzzles are satisfying and offer just enough challenge for the game to maintain a casual and relaxed feel overall. The way all aspects of the game, especially the narrative, come together so well is a definite highlight of the game and helps it to feel like a full, well-rounded experience. I thoroughly enjoyed this title and would highly recommend it to fans of puzzle games!

[b]WANT TO KNOW MORE?[/b]
My full review of this game where I go into detail about gameplay, narrative, and styling is available on [url=https://indie-hive.com/the-last-campfire/]Indie Hive[/url].

146501240.review: A cute little heart-warming (and heart-wrenching) puzzle adventure. The cutesy aesthetics may be a bit deceiving at first, as the underlying themes can be quite heavy, if you make an effort to understand the message. The dreamy soundtrack sets the solemn tone flawlessly with the help of a soothing voice actress/narrator. Game-play wise, the puzzles' difficulty are varied (I personally got stuck on one for a bit longer), though they may ultimately feel a bit easy for more hardcore riddle solvers - the more 'difficult' ones can be skipped, afaik. I believe the game is best enjoyed playing with a partner/child at a slower pace, letting the theme and story carry you along. It can be quite a tear-jerking experience!

146479036.review:
This game finds itself in an awkward place/space of being too easy for adults puzzles-wise and not really suitable for/comprehensible to kids. It's too childish for grown-ups and too philosophical for children. I can't say the philosophy is that deep, it's just too dark for children. Some praise the voice actress, saying she conjures up nostalgical feelings. In my opinion, it was annoying to the nth degree. Delivering in a fixed, unchanging manner and almost devoid of emotion because of that. I wished there was nothing but music in this game. That kind of killed the appeal for me.
I do like puzzlers, I can absolutely enjoy very accessible ones but please don't treat me as if I was a child. It's either or. Or be extraordinarily original and bring it on then.
Beautiful graphics, cute design. This cuteness doesn't really marry well with the melancholical touch of the game. It could have been an interesting mix but it turned out to be a mismatch. One third in the game, and both cuteness and melancholy start to pall on you.

Comforting, soothing, healing. A sound story told well. Some repetition and hand holding, but the messages of affirmation, mutual aid and validity of one's feelings and needs serve a deeper purpose. Puzzle difficulty doesn't progress consistently, especially disappointed with some of the later ones.

145121678.review:
"The Last Campfire" es una joya en el mundo de los videojuegos que merece toda la atención que pueda recibir. Este juego de aventuras independiente de Hello Games te transporta a un mundo mágico y emocionalmente conmovedor que te dejará sin aliento desde el principio hasta el final.

En primer lugar, la narrativa es un punto destacado. La historia sigue a Ember, una adorable criatura en busca de su camino de regreso a casa en un mundo misterioso lleno de desafíos y personajes fascinantes. La historia es conmovedora y te sumergirá en un viaje emocional, tratando temas como la esperanza, la soledad y la redención. Cada personaje que encuentras tiene su propia historia, lo que enriquece aún más el mundo y te hace sentir una profunda empatía por ellos.

La mecánica de juego es igualmente impresionante. "The Last Campfire" se destaca por sus rompecabezas ingeniosos y variados que van desde simples acertijos hasta desafíos complejos que te harán pensar fuera de la caja. La satisfacción de resolver estos rompecabezas es incomparable y te mantendrá comprometido a medida que avanzas en la historia.

Gráficamente, el juego es una obra maestra visual. Los diseños de personajes y escenarios son hermosos, con un estilo artístico único que crea un ambiente encantador y atractivo. La música y la banda sonora son igualmente impresionantes, añadiendo profundidad emocional a la experiencia y sumergiéndote aún más en este mundo cautivador.

Lo que realmente distingue a "The Last Campfire" es su capacidad para tocar tu corazón. Este juego te hará sentir una amplia gama de emociones, desde la tristeza hasta la alegría, a medida que te sumerges en su historia y conectas con sus personajes. Es una experiencia que te recordará el poder de los videojuegos como una forma de arte para contar historias.

En resumen, "The Last Campfire" es una obra maestra de la narrativa y los rompecabezas que te sumergirá en un mundo mágico y emocionalmente conmovedor. Es una experiencia que no debes perderte y que te recordará por qué los videojuegos pueden ser una forma de arte tan poderosa.

144363118.review:
🔥 The Last Campfire: A Cozy Puzzle Adventure with Heart 🧩

🌲 Introduction:
"The Last Campfire" weaves a tale of embers and lost souls through stunning visuals, soothing narration, and engaging puzzles. It's a game that appeals to both the seasoned puzzle enthusiast and the casual gamer seeking a touching story. Below, we explore what makes this title shine brightly and where it may flicker.

✅ Pros:

    Gorgeous Graphics: Beautiful art style and unique character designs set the mood.
    Narration: Fully-voiced narrator enhances immersion.
    Puzzle Variety: A mix of puzzles and clever mechanics keep players engaged.
    Engaging Story: Sweet and thoughtful narrative, touching on themes like hope and compassion.
    Atmosphere: Relaxing forest setting and crafted riddles evoke ancient civilizations and primitive technology.
    Accessible Gameplay: Puzzles are challenging but not overly hard, offering a chill experience.
    Short but Sweet: A concise experience that avoids becoming repetitive.

❌ Cons:

    Inconsistent Puzzle Complexity: Lack of gradual buildup to more complex levels.
    Navigation Issues: Overworld's lack of clear direction may lead to confusion.
    Clunky Controls: May feel like a port; running requires holding multiple keys.
    Limited Options Access: Menu accessibility only from the main screen.
    Simplistic Storytelling: Story may feel spoonfed, suiting more a children's game.
    Motion Sickness Concern: Constantly moving world may affect some players.

🪵 Conclusion:
With its blend of beautiful visuals, calming ambiance, and engaging puzzles, "The Last Campfire" offers a gentle journey into a world of hope, respect, and mutual aid. While not without its flaws, such as clunky controls and varying puzzle complexity, it remains a touching experience that resonates long after the final puzzle is solved. If you're in search of a brief but meaningful gaming escape, this cozy indie title may be the warm embrace you need. 🔥🌳

Beneath its cute exterior is a thoughtful and moving examination of self-worth, existential worry, and the importance of helping each other on our respective journeys. The puzzles are fun too, if not exceptionally challenging.

[Very minor spoilers below]

One of the things that stuck out to me as you go about helping other lost travelers is there are a few who you simply cannot help. One of them says something like "I'm not ready to let go of this way I'm feeling." That one really hit home, and caused me to wonder how many times I've been that person myself. The fact that they were able to infuse this sort of poignancy into what could have been a simple game about collecting trinkets makes this a game worth recommending.

143516159.review:
It is understandable that the puzzle must not be too hard, especially in a story-driven game where puzzle served as a background. But does it have to be this trivial? Like, even for the optional extra puzzle?? So if you're looking for a puzzle, look elsewhere.

The game feature no quality-of-life: no map or quick travel at all. The collectible done wrong on many aspects -- neither immersive where you practically miss something due to the lack of knowledge (cuz it has found/total counter), nor encourage a completionism (no grand-reward after full collection, has a point of no return where you can't go back to collecting). So if you're looking for an exploration, look elsewhere.

The Last Campfire was a very pleasant surprise, I expected a classic gameplay and puzzles that I would spend hours on. But the opposite was true.

The game has plenty of moments where you say "aww" and smile thoughtfully because you think of some of those lost souls too. 

You don't play for a long time, and maybe that's a plus, as the game would become slightly repetitive and lose that initial charm. So - short, but not too short. 

The puzzles are straightforward, you don't spend much time on them, so don't expect any great challenge. If you can't do it from one side, you can do it from the other.

The biggest surprise was the dubbing, which was pleasant to listen to and fit perfectly even though all the characters were dubbed the same. 

In short, there is always beauty in simplicity. 

Plus, the Embers look like pillows. :)

The stranger said [i]"Take care of those you care about the most"[/i] // Ember could not help. Not all problems were puzzles to be solved.

142432907.review:
A solid example of a game that uses puzzle solving as a parable for dealing with difficult emotions. If you're looking for a hard puzzler, or just not fond of games that shine specifically because of their narrative--rather than their gameplay--then I'd be cautious about this one and look for sales.  However, If you love games that shine by combining all of their elements into a greater whole--and especially if you're onboard to get all blubbery over a couple of sock monsters having a very difficult time--this one will satisfy. It has the added bonus of doing a good job of being family friendly without feeling too young for adult players. This can serve as a great tool for both introducing any audience to gaming while also providing langue and examples regarding emotional processing. 

Just go in knowing that there are some clunky PC controls, consider breaking out a controller, and plan to have a straightforward, casual experience. The game does exactly what it says on the tin, and is never trying to trick you. Which is deeply appropriate for the story it's telling, but can result in experienced gamers being deeply confused about what to do with a second bowl of soup.  

I just want the frozen golem to have soup. 
Please. 
It's so cold.

A cute game but not for me.

Pros: 
Absolutely gorgeous graphics, unique character designs, etc.
Fully-voiced narrator if you're into that.
Variety of puzzles
Some clever puzzle mechanics
Interesting world to explore

Cons:
Puzzle complexity varies wildly, has no lead-up to more complex levels
Overworld doesn't have strong visual language leading you places; I like secrets as much as the next person, but going around in circles isn't very fun
Extremely clunky controls - feels like a port
You have to hold 2 keys AND direct your character in order to run??????
Options are only accessible from the main menu. Why do games do this.
Story feels like I'm being spoonfed, which ig is okay for a kid's game

A lot of people go on about how good this game is, and I'm glad they had a good time, it's just not for me. I was forcing myself to start the game and try and make more progress (which the map confusion made ever more fun, bc every detail of this thing slides out of my mind the second I close it out) and just couldn't have any fun aside from some odd "oh, that was a neat puzzle detail" moments.

Anyways, I hope other people enjoy this more than I did.

What a nice, little gem of a game! 
Mechanic-wise, most of the gameplay is consisted of puzzles, relatively simple, well executed, and with very small difficulty factor. Graphics and overall aesthetic is superb, and ties well with the atmosphere of the story, the game's best element.

Story follows Ember, an elemental(?) entity travelling through what can be described as the "middle world", the place between the living and the afterlife. Ember's purpose is to help others like them to process their past regrets and fears, serving as a beautiful allegory for the human concept of death, and the feeling of loss that comes with it.

In the end, the game might be described as a well-crafted metaphorical journey about death, grief, and the fear of moving on. Highly recommended.

141807373.review: The Last Campfire delivers a fun and meaningful experience, even if perhaps it is lacking in ambition and in need of some detailing. The story centers around a race of fantastical creatures known as the embers and the daunting journey they embark upon in their dying days. On the path to their mythical destination, however, the the sorrows and stresses of life sometimes causes some of the embers to turn to stone, thus becoming "forlorn". Your character is a brave ember intent on reaching out to the forlorn and guiding them back on the path of their mysterious pilgrimage. The gameplay of The Last Campfire is centered around a series of diverse and unique puzzles which your character must solve in order to find these forlorn and break them out of the stone state. The art and sound-track work with the other elements to create an environment that is cozy and wondrous but with a bleak and ominous undercurrent.  The Last Campfire explores serious ideas of inadequacy, hopelesness, and grief with a beauty and gentleness that adds complex maturity to an otherwise cute and simple game. One of the best bits about this game probably has to be the narrator, whose dramatically powerful but soothingly gentle voice saturated in a Nordic accent always captivates attention and enhances the gameplay throughout. If you are looking for a sweet, simple, and short game then The Last Campfire is an excellent choice.

141718975.review:
I am not a fan of Bjork, since I have found her always a little unsettling.
Reading some other reviews here, I can definitely relate to people complaining about the narrator
(which is not Bjork but whose Scandinavian accent and childish voice definitely resemble hers).
I don't think this game is a good fit for younger kids with the skeletons and almost-jump-scares.

Having said that, I do believe this game could be a great one for older children with a parent guiding them.
Because while it might be obvious what the theme of the game is [spoiler], since there are ghosts, creatures that are reluctant of moving from their place, skeletons, the ominous narrator which always mentions fear and grief,[/spoiler] this could be an opportunity to explain it. The puzzles are easy, the game doesn't actually have any real dangers and the story is a simple one to follow.

After finishing the game I think the narrator did a great job, because, for me, she captured strangeness and fear in her performance. The game was not meant to be fully cute considering the theme. And the third person narration, which I have seen others ridicule, makes sense [spoiler] because the dead can no longer speak and we have to carry on their stories [/spoiler].

There is not much walking, considering the metroidvania approach of powers and items unlocking alternate paths, unless you specifically go back to the completed areas.
[spoiler] While I would have just locked them to not confuse people, there is a reason for them to be empty and feel like a waste of time.[/spoiler]

The sadness makes sense if you understand it. People probably have false expectations judging by the colors and simple game-play. I was definitely not looking into playing another child-trapped-in-a-scary-world-indie-game or a puzzle game which eats my life away. The developers somehow made the cliche work and the puzzles to be adequately rewarding for their time. They stopped just before making them grinding.

Regarding the game requiring dexterity, I played with a controller and besides finding it difficult to leave with the boat, I had no challenges. What I think another reviewer is referring to is a bug regarding pigs which also confused me at first. Some pigs clip or jump around, which might make it seem like speed is needed. But if you realize [spoiler]pig filth is something you can walk through[/spoiler] and that slides can be used [spoiler]by all moving characters[/spoiler], there should be no issues I think.

[quote]Not all problems were puzzles to be solved[/quote]

140832881.review:
The game surpassed my expectations with its charming and well-crafted design. The puzzles, while relatively straightforward, contribute to the smooth pacing of the game. Surprisingly, the world-building and narrative are fleshed out, despite the game's short length. The beautiful artwork, featuring vibrant colors and clean lines, evokes memories of my favorite game, Journey. Moreover, the narrator's presence adds a nostalgic touch, making me feel like a child being read to.

While the puzzles provided a good challenge, I only needed to seek help once. I highly recommend this game, especially considering the additional enjoyable puzzles. It's a fantastic game that skillfully explores themes of hope, grief, death, and moving on, all wrapped up in a cute puzzle game with delightful music. The puzzles strike the perfect balance between being challenging and achievable, stealing a piece of my heart along the way.

Beyond its stunning visuals and smooth gameplay, the game boasts an intuitive interface. The emotional depth of the dialogue and story caught me off guard, as it warmed my heart and showcased incredible empathy and depth. The captivating aesthetic offers a relaxing experience, accompanied by a mysterious story and a wonderful message. Although the puzzles are generally straightforward, the sense of accomplishment upon completing them remains satisfying.

This polished game gem shines with remarkable storytelling, featuring a simple yet meaningful narrative filled with metaphors. Despite the initially pushy narration, it contributes to the fairytale-like experience. The excellent gameplay introduces fresh mechanics, and the puzzles strike a perfect balance of challenges. Overall, I highly recommend this game, especially considering its price. It's truly a worthwhile investment.

And if you need a helpful walkthrough guide, I've created one specifically for this game. You can find it here:
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2860659777

139866737.review:
This is a good, though not great game, that acts as a simple means of relaying its story concept while being an overall relaxing experience. This is essentially an exploration game with puzzle elements. Ember, who I guess is a gender neutral symbol of a flame, is trying to get out of wherever he or she is. Basically you move from area to area unlocking puzzles by talking to certain characters. You have to solve a certain number of these puzzles to light the campfire and move onto the next area. It's a short game, taking only about five hours to complete, but the content overall works. 

I just have two things I really don't like about this game:
- The lack of any platforming or combat aspect
- The narrator

The narrator is a little girl with a European accent and she talks constantly. After a while it's a little less jarring, but for the first hour or so it's really irritating that she has to narrate every single thing that's happening on the screen, being the only voice in the game. It's not really a big deal, nor does it ruin the game, but it feels out of place hearing this disembodied voice talk constantly. With that said, the environments are nice and simplistic. Most of the puzzles just involve pushing blocks, some are so easy that they take no effort to solve. There's only two that I really had to pause to think about to solve, and even then it only took about five minutes. You don't even need to complete all the puzzles to finish the game since you only need to do about 2/3 in each area to progress, though you won't unlock the respective achievement.

With that said, each puzzle does have this "aha!" moment where you figure out what you're supposed to do, and I can credit the game for never being frustrating, as puzzle games often are frustrating. It might be a tad bit too easy considering that some of the puzzles just solve themselves if you manipulate the blocks for a few minutes. The final puzzle isn't even a puzzle, I'm not sure why they even included it. I understand that it's essentially a kid's game but throwing in a couple uber hard ones probably would've made the game more memorable. And the fact that you can't jump can sometimes make the game feel weird, since often your solution is to climb to the highest point in the area by manipulating the blocks around you.

It's a simple game with great music, a nice concept and solid presentation. Recommended if you like exploration games, as a puzzle game it's not really that great but the experience overall is solid.

100% recommend the game for anyone that likes this genre or style of game. I LOVE seeing small indie games like this get such positive feedback and this one has definitely earned it's +98% overwhelmingly positive reviews as of this post.

Not a game I would have ever found on my own and super glad I stumbled across it. Its 80% off at them moment and an absolute steal at that price. 

As most reviews willl mention, visuals, art style, story, and audio are all on point. Ill admit, I was surprised at how varied each of the puzzles were given just the few mechanics you are given.. but they all work great and some made me sit and think for a second or two before figuring it out. 

I think my only "complaint" would be that one or two mechanics I didn't realize were mechanics so I got stumped on a couple of puzzles longer than I should have.. i.e. not realizing the blocks you roll can roll up one of the "half step" platforms... Which ended up being vital to solving the thing. BUT that could have been my own duh dumb moment too. 

All said and done - great game to sink 5-6 hours into if you're taking your time, exploring, finding all the lost diaries, etc. You might be able to do it in half the time if you're blowing through and not completing each area. (Only requires you to do about half the area before giving you the option to move on) but most that pick this game up aren't going to be doing it for the speed run and would likely be looking for everything anyway.

Enjoy this beauty!

Wow, what a gem! This is a cute little puzzler with a lovely aesthetic and surprisingly touching story. Visually, the game is a treat, and the sound design and music are very nice. The puzzles are a good level of challenging. Nothing very tough, but some decent mindbenders. My playtime clocked in at about 7 hours with 100% completion, which felt about right. I wasn't chomping at the bit for more due to short runtime, nor did the game overstay its welcome.

Overall, this is a game that would be very good, but is elevated so much further than that by the truly spectacular narration. Rachel August does an amazing job in this, guiding you through the game and giving voice to the characters you meet. The feeling I get from her narration is that of a older sister reading a very old fairytale to a younger sibling. It's equal parts relaxing and charming. Again, the game would be quite good on its own, but wow, the narration adds to the experience very substantially.

Would recommend this to basically anyone, unless you're a diehard puzzle hater. Even then, would probably still be worth it for the experience.

Really enjoying the game so far. It's one of those games that gives you minimal information and hints as you go and you pretty much have to figure things out for yourself which I appreciate as I feel like a lot of games spend too much time babying people in a tutorial setting, 

This game has a variation of puzzles but the one's I've encountered so far have not been mechanically hard to complete they've been something that you need to sit and work out logically (opposed to a platforming-ability-test.) 

Enjoying it so far, some of the messages/dialogue that are included in the game I really appreciate "not every problem is something that is ready to be resolved right now" is very appropriate with the themes of moving on, grief, feeling trapped in a situation.

139034953.review:
Era uno de mis pendientes en la lista de deseados y ha sido uno de mis regalos de cumple del que he disfrutado muchísimo.

🔥🎆🔥🎆🔥🎆🔥🎆🔥🎆🔥🎆🔥🎆
The Last Campfire sigue a Ember, una pequeña ascua que busca encontrar el camino a la llama eterna (una especie de más allá) que es el destino de todo su pueblo una vez llega el momento de la partida. Ember no estará sola. En su camino se encontrará con otras ascuas que se han convertido en almas en pena debido a que todos los problemas que vivieron han podido con ellas. Unos fantasmas se nos aparecerán para pedirnos que les echemos una mano a cambio de su ayuda en el camino.
Me encanta ver como a medida que vas consiguiendo salvarlas ellas irán a esperar a la hoguera con el fantasma y las demás haciendo como una pequeña gran familia que sigue tus pasos y que no te dejarán solo…

Todo se basa en ayudar, guiar a quien lo necesite. Pero da unas lecciones preciosas y de vital importancia para todo el mundo. Parece incluso un juego para niños, pero es más profundo de lo que parece.

La voz narradora, de hecho está contándote una historia, nos ayuda a entender las emociones de Ember , de las ascuas y también de una tortuga cocinera que ha dejado de hacer lo que ama, de un viejo pescador que se siente vacío, de un cerdo enorme al que nada le satisface…
🔥🎆🔥🎆🔥🎆🔥🎆🔥🎆🔥🎆🔥🎆🔥🎆

Me gusta esa imagen que quieren dar de no son problemas tan simples ¿y cómo? A través de puzles y de las historias de las heridas más profundas sacadas a la luz.

¡Es muy creativo y original a parte de que cuenta con un diseño precioso!

This is an adorable and pretty game! I loved the variety of environments, and there was a nice cast of characters to meet.
Sometimes I did feel like the narration and animations slowed down the game a bit. It's supposed to be kinda like a storybook, but the writing could be a bit "tell, don't show", even when the player could see what was going on. Still, the narration was pretty charming, and I do think it added a lot to the characters (I especially liked the Builder).
The visuals were really nice, and the environments were super pretty! The bloom could be a bit much, and it felt like I couldn't really see some details with how bright it was. I think the caves, both at the beginning and the end, were my favorite locations. I guess I just love dark areas with bright colors lol.
Overall, a nice little cute game with good puzzles (the extra puzzles really stumped me at first). It's also fun to try to find all the Forgotten Things. (Although I missed [i] ONE [/i] of them, [b] [i] aaaaaggghhhh![/i][/b])

138659106.review:
A very relaxing puzzler. Nothing difficult, but (importantly for my tastes) not repetitive - there's something new in most puzzles, so it's broad and not deep (As a contrast to Sokoban, Kine, Monster's Expedition or Stephen's Sausage Roll, which are deep and not broad - there have a few mechanics and they're explored so thoroughly that an impatient person will get sick of them).

It's not long (it took me 5 hours not hurrying to 100% it, including probably half an hour of trying to find the one "guy on a grassy cliff" I was missing in the Forest, that was just a southwest-pointing junction that was hidden by camera angles, the most frustrating part).

The graphics are cute, the animation is smooth, the gameplay is solid, the sound and music are nice, and the voiced narration is ... unusual; a lady with a norweigan accent, that frequently sounds a bit welsh. It's mostly good, except when she's narrating the words of another character and reads what's clearly written as another accent (like "ooh, ah've lost me 'at", not a real example) with no vocal variation at all. A scandinavian woman's accent reading stereotype cornwall-esque fisherman dialogue is a bit strange.

138352409.review:
A pretty well-balanced puzzle game. It has two levels: main story where you move through the different parts of the game world, collect some items and use them to unlock more of that world, and some pure puzzle rooms where you solve a problem with a set of different mechanics in a sandbox setting. The items-related part might be a bit too easy because it's always obvious which item should be used where and which you need to find to unlock something. 

I quite liked the world exploration: it's not completely linear, and you can run around between a few connected areas to unlock all puzzles and pieces of the storyline. Sandbox puzzles vary in difficulty, some are too easy and get solved in seconds, others are more interesting and made me think and try a few times. I wish the game had a bit more of the challenging puzzles, at least as optional challenge.

The story is a bit melancholic, but leaves you with hope and touches some deep topics. All this with some very nice, even cute narration.

P.S. the game should have been named "Forlorn". It's a cool word and is used a lot in the game

Aprovecho para felicitar el espléndido trabajo realizado por la narradora del juego, Rachel August. Mi más sincera enhorabuena por tal hermoso e inmersivo resultado logrado a través de su voz.
En resumen, si te gustan los juegos temática puzzle lo recomiendo y con creces.

Tried the demo last year, and I knew straight away I am going to get this game.

The last campfire is a very cozy puzzle game of you playing as Ember, the cute tiny creature who tried to help rescue other 'forlorn' to get back their flame. Surprisingly a wholesome game with a serious undertone about losing hope and depression. However, little ember will try to help and give some advice that is applicable for us players. In fact, the game hits me hard at times and got me a little emotional. 

Fully narrated with a bit of accent, and she also had lisp - it is not a bad thing; I find it matches the vibe of the game.

The only downside, as a puzzle players I found a lot of the puzzles (especially the last leg of the game)  very simple and easy. It felt a little bit underwhelming. This game has a bit of challenging puzzles as well, so It has a good range but mostly pretty simple puzzles. 

Definitely would play again this game sometime, recommended.

137589772.review:
The Last Campfire makes for a great weekend game. You know the kind; it doesn't take too long, can finish it in maybe two or three sessions, is fairly relaxed and doesn't test you too much. That's not to say there's nothing to the game, but it clearly doesn't aspire to be more than a pleasant and charming experience with a thoughtful message underneath it all. As a puzzle game, there were only a couple of instances where I was left thinking for the solution for longer than it took for me to actually do all the inputs to make it happen. Part of that is that the game makes it incredibly clear what it wants you to do and that when you are solving something it's pretty bitesize.

The trade-off is that the puzzles end up not being overly challenging, but I'd rather that than anything feeling unfair or completely esoteric. There are a few dozen collectables to find which break up the pacing as they're typically found through exploration, although some do come with their own puzzles that can be quite fun to solve. The narrative driving you on is again pretty simple and is delivered, along with all of the text, in voice over. I went between finding the tone of this spot-on and annoying, though with specific regards to the latter, I do think children would actually engage with this part of the game quite well. In fact between that and the relative simplicity of the puzzles, this would probably be a great puzzle game for younger kids. 

At the end of the day it's a charming and satisfying game that doesn't outstay its welcome. I'd have liked it to push you a bit more, but over the course of the weekend I enjoyed it enough.

136803030.review:
[b]“I want to move on…”[/b]
[i]-Little Ember when I take an hour to solve the simplest puzzle[/i]
[hr][/hr]

A “[b]detour[/b]” ( diː.tʊə ) is defined as: “[]A long or roundabout route that is taken to avoid something or to visit somewhere along the way”.

[b]The Last Campfire[/b] fits this definition to a tee.
It’s a game about missing opportunities, being led astray and not being able to face fears or have resolution to pull oneself out of a predicament, but still pushing on and achieving your end.

Now, these feelings are nice and all, but how do they translate it into gameplay?

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
You’ll be exploring areas centered around a same sized hub area, in which you’ll solve some puzzles to unlock shortcuts and paths to other puzzles that happen inside the minds of other characters.
Once solved you will move on to the next Area + Sub-Area system.

[h1]Story[/h1]
Told in short cutscenes at the beginning and end but mostly through findable scraps of paper during gameplay.

[h1]X-Factor[/h1]
Graphics are great, music is serviceable, narration is strangely out of place at first but quickly grows on you.

[h1]Downsides[/h1]
My only critic is that the game doesn’t do a great job to translate what feel they were going for into gameplay, making you feel like you’re meeting funny characters while just solving puzzles in a slightly gloomy world and only first and last 20 minutes of the game truly matter to understand it.
[hr][/hr]

Still a recommendation from me, I may not agree with the “Overwhelmingly Positive” but it’s a good little game nonetheless.

136791233.review:
You can interpret this game in one of two ways: a cute little game about helping cute little characters, or a pretty dark game that discusses what happens when a soul gets lost on its way to the afterlife.

However you interpret it, it’s a great little stress-free game. There’s plenty of hints on what to do next if you’re ever stuck, so you can just casually play your way through.

I looked at it from a darker angle, and it was pretty well done. You can kind of sympathise with all of the characters and feel for them. Especially the twist at the end before the final puzzle made you feel for that character.

Controls are well made and it runs perfectly on the Steam Deck - I never had a single issue the entire playthrough.

The voice acting I thought fitted the game perfectly. Usually I’m not a fan of narrators talking about every action, but it worked here and the actor’s voice suited the kind of Nordic theme of the game really well.

Overall, I’d 100% recommend this for those looking for a nice easy enjoyable game to play through.

136244528.review:
The Last Campfire es, a pocas palabras, una experiencia tiernamente bonita.
Comenzando con su apartado artístico, hermosísimo; tanto en los diseños de personajes como en sus paisajes, ambientes y/o efectos. El uso de la paleta de colores es tan bello, que va en sintonía total con cada modelado, destacando ese estilo tierno, regordete y hermoso que engancha visualmente durante la aventura.
- Duración de 5-7 horas aprox. Lo cual es correcto, punto.
- La banda sonora por su parte si puede ser mejorable, por que, sin estar mal para nada (ya que ambienta y sabe sonar en los momentos adecuados...) no es recordable como tal. Por su parte el uso de un motivo, una melodía que destaque como tema central hubiera potenciado mucho más la experiencia. De hecho, es más bien curioso notar el mismo acorde de pocas notas (puede que a modo de guiño) resonando durante algunos momentos puntuales, perteneciente a la otra obra del estudio de HELLO GAMES, "No Man's Sky".

¿Pero de que va el juego en sí?
The Last Campfire es un juego de puzzles como mecánica principal, pero que, con un mínimo de atención, son todos solucionables, de hecho, entre 2 a 3 puzzles serían los más "desafiantes". Por ende, se nota la intención de tratar a los acertijos como un medio de juego entre cada avance de zona, más no como una barrera que se opone al jugador. 
Y la razón de esto es: Su historia. 

La historia contada con algunas escenas y sin diálogos por parte de los personajes sabe comunicar visualmente de forma correcta la situación, la soledad, el miedo, la pérdida o la desolación. Los textos en pantalla por su parte son simples, oraciones con enunciados cortos, los cuales pueden ser entendidos con total tranquilidad. Pero justamente ahí radica uno de los puntos más fuertes. Al leer entre líneas. Las oraciones pueden ser interpretadas sin mucho esfuerzo o disección literaria, sin embargo, la carga emotiva en la gran macro-forma de las cosas, denota la intencionalidad por parte de los desarrolladores para intentar transmitir emociones complejas.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Lo único chocante (bajo mi punto de vista personal) es la voz narradora. Que, estando presente de inicio a fin, siempre lee todo en pantalla, siendo por momentos levemente molesta. Pero no porque lo haga mal, de hecho, en algunos momentos es un disfrute escuchar las acentuaciones silábicas a modo de jugueteo verbal/sonoro de varias palabras. Pero muchas veces mantiene una neutralidad monótona que aporta poco cuando se lee más rápido los textos con la vista, mientras la voz aún habla.
Otro punto regular, es que es una voz única (una sola persona) narrando siempre, con lo cual podrían haber optado por mínimo conseguir unas cuantas personas más para los distintos personajes, o bien incluso, dejar la parte de locución de la narradora como una voz en off general y para cada uno de los personajes el recurso de "onomatopeyas/ruiditos" cuando dicen algo, evitando la intervención de la narradora en todo momento.
Como dije, este es un punto de vista personal en cuanto a lo mejorable, porque también hay una opción en el juego para bajar el volumen de la narradora, sin embargo, ahí se notan ciertos huecos de silencio en el juego. Y de lo que he visto, hay personas a las que les encanta y fascinó la narradora por su forma de hablar tan apacible y demás. Por ello en este apartado reitero, no es que este mal, pero, dentro de la perspectiva personal, trastabilla.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Volviendo a la historia y para finalizar, la intención de los autores en como manejaron el relato a la par de las mecánicas como para plantear la experiencia jugable a través de puzzles, es lo que se queda con el jugador. Los escenarios, los fragmentos de historia y demás plantean una micro-narrativa que motiva al jugador a sacar sus propias conclusiones. Porque dentro de lo que acontece en la aventura, si bien hay un eje central, la interpretación final de todo lo sucedido es libre. Lo cual refuerza aún más la esencia de lo bello del juego.

Recomendado sin dudas.
¡Adelante, probadlo!

135906798.review:
Ah, The Last Campfire, the game that makes you feel like you're snuggled up by a cozy fire on a chilly evening.

This game is like a warm hug in gaming form. You play as Ember, a little wanderer who's lost in a mysterious world and trying to find her way home. Along the way, you'll encounter a variety of quirky characters and solve puzzles that feel both challenging and satisfying.

But let's talk about the real star of the show here: the art and music. The visuals are simply breathtaking, with vibrant colors and whimsical landscapes that look like they came straight out of a storybook. And the music is equally enchanting, with gentle melodies that make you feel like you're in a dream.

The Last Campfire is a game that's meant to be savored. It's not about winning or losing; it's about the journey. The puzzles are designed to be challenging but not frustrating, and the story is full of heart and emotion.

All in all, The Last Campfire is a must-play for anyone who wants to escape the stresses of the world and get lost in a magical adventure. It's like a warm blanket on a cold day, a cup of hot cocoa by the fire. So cozy up, relax, and let Ember lead the way.

135417461.review: [u]The Last Campfire[/u] is more than just a game - it's a work of art. Upon launching the game, I was immediately transported to a vivid world of stunning visuals that immersed me into its universe and storyline. The level design was breathtakingly beautiful and easy to comprehend, with puzzles that were well thought out but not overly complex. The music and voiceover also added to the emotional journey and storyline, perfectly complementing the overall experience.However, what truly set [u]The Last Campfire[/u] apart from any other games I've played were its characters. The protagonist, a lost ember, embodies hope and perseverance in a world that can seem bleak at times. As I journeyed with them, I encountered a diverse cast of characters, each unique and endearing in their own way. Whether it was the old fisherman I met or the wise old turtle, every interaction felt like a moment of genuine connection.The way in which all the game's elements complemented each other was truly remarkable. Every aspect was carefully crafted to enhance the others, resulting in an experience that exceeded the sum of its parts. [u]The Last Campfire[/u] is not just a game - it is a magnificent narrative that is so masterfully told, you'll find yourself wanting to relive it again and again.

134874622.review:
[h1]Relaxing Puzzle Adventure of Hope and Kindness[/h1]

A delightful puzzle adventure game that is perfect for those who want a relaxing and chill gaming experience, not much action or complex puzzles here. What it does have though is a heartwarming story of hope, compassion, and kindness, brought to life by Ember, the game's protagonist, as she helps the forlorns find their purpose again. The puzzles in the game are cleverly designed and provide a sense of satisfaction, without requiring too much thinking.

The game's art style is beautiful and inviting, and the soundtrack is a joy to listen to. The attention to detail in the game is impressive, and the collectibles add depth and richness to the story without being necessary for completion. Additionally, the game has no missable achievements, which is great for completionists.

[b]The normal price of the game is a bit high, so I would wait for it to be on sale. That said I recommend it as a perfect addition to your sit-back-and-relax games collection, if that sort of game appeals to you.[/b]

134319968.review:
The Last Campfire is a really lovely game that has a poignant and touching story.

Its greatest strength is that it's very atmospheric. The environments coupled with the music and narration create an engaging experience. A lot of the time I just played silently because I was captivated. The music is beautiful and is quite melancholic. There is one narrator who does all of the dialogue which makes it feel almost like a fable.

The puzzles were well-integrated and fun. Some were challenging but never frustrating. You can also see if you're on the right path because snippets of narration will start playing! 

The characters are super charming and I'm in love with little Ember. The animation where Ember approaches a forlorn melts my heart. The character interactions show the importance of compassion.

I think the story could be a [i]bit[/i] tighter. I'm not asking for it to be straightforward, as the slight ambiguity is good. But something that is open to interpretation can still be well-constructed.
I think there could be additional parts to bring it more together - in particular, the characters and their personal stories, such as The Wanderer. Maybe some more cutscenes? There are scattered notes in hidden chests but these are optional for the player.

Having said all that, I don't have a problem with the story overall. I guess I just wanted more, because I liked it a lot! I was absorbed the whole time.

Definitely play this beautiful game!

134153907.review:
TLDR: Beautiful, moving, gentle, and peaceful. 

[b][u]General Thoughts/Overview:[/u][/b]


What an adorable little puzzle game. I ate it in a single sitting, the second such occurrence in the last couple of weeks… maybe I need to play more puzzle games. 
Anyhow, the last campfire has you guide your little character, Ember, through a series of environments, with several veins of puzzle to solve along the way. The main story seems to be about finding ones way home, by locating and restoking ‘campfires’, (read ‘bloody massive bonfires’) but reveals itself to be something a little more than that in theme. You progress by helping other characters through simple and gentle puzzles that generally match the sort of thing you were doing in the environment.

[b][u]Pros:[/u][/b]
[list][*] The ambiance is wonderful. The music, art style, movements, and characters are just… delightful. It’s all very gentle. 
[*] The puzzles are simple and immensely solvable. Some are overly simple and just in the way, while others require a smudging of thought. Not a single one was frustrating or difficult, however, and it really helps the pace. 
[*] It touches on quite dark themes very gently. The whole hope thing really hit home for me, and I felt it dealt with the undertones quite well. That said, it [i]does[/i] beat you over the head with them, so there is that. 
[/list]

[b][u]Cons:[/u][/b]
[list][*] Controlling blocks with the instrument was just terrible when using the mouse. It was the only truly frustrating part of this game. 
[*] The movement is delightfully rapid, allowing you to really cover ground, but the pathfinding was off, and the character has a habit of getting stuck on terrain and/or bugging through things while running around. So the collisions and general movements were not great in a game where you spend most of your time moving. 
[*] The narrator gets a bit old by the end of the game. She has a lovely voice, but in one sitting of 6 hours, I got a bit tired… Maybe if I’d broken the game up a little it would have been less grating by the end. 
[/list]

[b][u]Suggested improvements:[/u][/b]
 [list][*] Fix collisions. 
[*] Fix mouse control of the instrument puzzles. 
[/list]


[b][u]Overall Recommendation:[/u][/b]


Yeah, this is a sweet little game. 
At the time of writing it is on sale on steam, and also part of a humble bundle, so it’s well priced and extremely good value for money respectively. 
This game is not for people who want dakka-dakka, whizz-bang, fast-paced action, or people who are out for a solid challenge. 
This game is simple enough and gentle enough that it would probably be good to play with kids, and is great for filthy casuals. 

Finally, my favourite factoid about this game; at time of writing 34.7% of people have finished the final puzzle, but only 34.6% of people have finished the game… this means that 1 in 1000 people spent the 6ish hours needed to beat the game, but then couldn’t be bothered to watch the final five minute cutscene… This is absolutely wild to me.

134013253.review:
What a lovely, lovely game.  It contains the essence of SPIRITFARER, the heart of A SHORT HIKE and delightfully creative puzzles that remind me of much more elegant, streamlined versions of the puzzles in Shadow of the TOMB RAIDER (seriously.)  There is definitely a bit of challenge in some of the puzzles, but I never got frustrated while trying to figure them out and, more importantly, the solutions always made sense.  Not once was I upset with how a puzzle was solved.  An absolute rarity in these types of games.  

Prior to completing this game, I would always recommend A SHORT HIKE to friends looking for a nice, relaxing game to play in under 10 hours, and I still definitely recommend that, but THE LAST CAMPFIRE has now jumped to the top of that list.  

If possible, I do recommend playing this with a joystick.  There are some very minor issues playing with the keyboard that affect the character's movement and ability to manipulate objects.  Basically, a lot of problems trying to do anything on the diagonal.  It's not game-breaking or even puzzle-breaking in any way, but if I had a joystick I would have switched right at the beginning to  save some minor frustration.  Even with those quite tiny issues, it doesn't affect my love of this game at all.

I rate this a 10 out of 10 and highly recommend it.   THE LAST CAMPFIRE is a soul-nourishing, heart-warming experience.

A quirky little puzzle game albeit a bit short. The artwork has that cell shaded vibe to it that is popular in so many little indie games lately, and it was a treat to explore and work on puzzles in it. The puzzles range from the incredibly easy to the occasional head scratcher and to be honest I don't feel that they were balanced at all. Instead of saving the more difficult ones towards the end it mostly felt like I would trip over a difficult one at a random interval and be stuck for a few minutes while I figured it out.

My only real big gripe is the camera is largely locked in. For a puzzle game that has hidden collectibles scattered around (although they're solely for lore and don't count towards achievements), it was frustrating to fight with the camera to see if there was anything actually hidden or if it was just an artistic way to hide a dead end.

I played this puzzle game when I wanted a break from the more difficult games I picked up and ended up enjoying it. The ending had a lot more weight to it than I expected for a 4 hour game and it surprisingly tugged at my heartstrings. I think this would be a good beginning puzzle game to play with along kids or someone just getting into gaming. Its not going to take the gaming world by storm but it did leave me with a sense of fulfillment when I beat it.

8.0/10.0

Delightful little puzzle game. 
Music is good and narrator is pleasant. 
Puzzles are not very hard and there is even a "explore" mode that skips most of the puzzles. (Not recommended as puzzle mechanics are cool) 
The story/theme is very clear and easy to understand but not heavy handed in any way.
The characters are adorable and there are all kinds of cute animations - the environment and levels remind me of Hob, but much simpler. 
Fairly short game, but doesn't feel rushed, perfect length. There are some harder puzzles in the menu if you want to play some more.

There are three different control schemes: Mouse only, Mouse and keyboard, Controller
They all work well, except mouse and keyboard can be a bit finicky when you want to rotate things with the arrow keys and row the boat. Nothing game breaking.

One slight annoyance is the boat undocking procedure, the button to row is the same button to climb back up the ladder, which sometimes makes it difficult to sail away.

All in all, great little game, plus there is a demo you can try before you buy!

The Last Campfire is a charming little puzzle game. You play as Ember, a little creature on a strange journey, who must solve puzzles (of the moving block, pulling levers, and pushing switches variety) to clear the path ahead, as well as free others of your kind who have given up hope and become "forlorn."

The atmosphere and graphical design is pleasant. The puzzles are sufficiently challenging so as not to be boring, but not too difficult to the point you have to consult a walkthrough online. The story is also narrated by a female voice with a vaguely foreign accent, which adds to the charm.

I finished the game in a little under eight hours (some of that time could have been spent paused), so it's pretty short, but definitely worth picking up on sale.

132698006.review:
I had this one in the library for a while, so I decided to knock it out.

[h1]PROS[/h1]
✅ I finished the game in a little over 6 hours. If you're not taking your time, I can easily see it as 4 hours or less. Essentially a nice little bite-sized game.
✅ Very relaxed and chill. No enemies to fight, and you can play it at your own pace.
✅ Cute art style and a charming aesthetic. Definitely a departure from Hello Games' first foray, "No Man's Sky."
✅ The story is thought provoking, without being mind-blowing. Just enough to make you think a little.
✅ Easy to 100% the achievements.

[h1]CONS[/h1]
❌ Most of the puzzles are rather easy, so don't look for too many brain twisters. There are a few tough ones, which make them feel out of place with the rest of the game though.
❌ There's no independent camera control, even though there are ways to see beyond the framed set pieces.
❌ There are a few texture overlapping issues. Not many, but you notice them easier because of that.
❌ The music and sound design are nothing to write home about.

[h1]OVERALL[/h1]
Recommended if you're looking for a quick game to get some achievements for and stay engaged while you do it. Perfectly cromulent.

132673259.review: The Last Campfire is a cute little adventure/puzzle game. It's got an adorable art style, the puzzles aren't that challenging however there are some good brain teasers mixed in, and the music and sound is all absorbing. I'd argue the games biggest strength is its narrative, not for its strength of writing (though it is good), or for its complexity, or even its uniqueness. It's a rather straightforward tale, with only a few moving parts. However, it's delivered with a rare sincerity and earnestness that was not only compelling but emotionally impactful. I could tell where about it was all going fairly early on (playing enough games or reading enough stories will do that), but in spite of that fact it still managed to illicit tears from me (the 2nd game to do so for me personally) by the end. It's a brief, enjoyable, satisfying experience that I'd highly recommend.

132626546.review: The Last Campfire is an absolutely stunningly beautiful game with a meaningful story.  The puzzles aren't particularly hard.  My five year old and I enjoyed playing together.  The scenery and puzzles kept him interested.  The gameplay is relaxing but emotional.   I highly recommend if you are looking for something to engage the mind after a long day.

132492416.review:
I loved this game - it was thoughtful and touching in the best way. I don't often manage to play games all the way to completion but the Last Campfire drew me in and I've played all the way to the end over the course of the last week or so. It's not a long game - it took me about thirteen hours altogether - but what it achieves in that time is wonderful. 
And even though I played through quite quickly, it is also a game that's easy to play in small chunks and that benefits from little breaks here and there to appreciate what you've done so far. The puzzles are a good mix of easy to learn yet thought provoking as the challenge increases and they contribute to the story telling in a meaningful way.
The first hour was a little slow, it seemed a a bit broken up by some of the puzzles, but once the way the game worked was established and I understood what the game was trying to do a little more, the rhythm of The Last Campfire and the ebb and flow of the story makes more sense. In a world with a lot going on (lots of it upsetting) this gentle hopeful game was exactly what I needed during a difficult time.

It definitely has a great soundtrack, it was pleasing to listen to while playing.

Sound Effects: 10/10
Whoever worked on the sound effects, let me tell you... you are amazing! My ears were super pleased with every sound effect. I especially loved the crispness of the campfire and the sound of chains.

Game Mechanics: 6/10
It was a bit wonky and I didn't really care much with the controls on the keyboard it didn't feel natural. It took a bit of time to get used to but still playable.

Bugs: 3/10
This game was really buggy. I constantly got stuck in walls or stairs. Two time I even got stuck under stairs and had to re-start the game because there was no way to get un-stuck. The biggest one though was that during my second to last play-through of it between each transition the game would break the screen. The screen would be split in half and mirrored upside down! I've never seen that happen in a game before! It definitely added an element of surprise but unfortunately it was unplayable and had to re-start the game a few times until it "calmed down".

Story: 8/10
Cute story about life and the struggles that come with it. 

Puzzles: 8/10
Pretty good puzzles, a lot of them were too easy. I got stumped in a few of them. I had to take a break and come back to 3 of them and I only had to look up the answer to 1 of them. I wish there was more balance in the complexity of the puzzles but otherwise enjoyable!

Price: (My range: Awful-Bad-FAIR-Good-Great)
The price is 14.99 which I find it to be fair for this game. 

Overall: It's a rounded up 8! It was definitely enjoyable to play although frustrating at times, I recommend this game!

131182684.review:
You play as a nameless Ember. One of many, all scattered to the winds. Most of the other embers have lost hope, and turned into petrified forms called Forlorn. You must seek each of them out, listen to their stories, solve puzzles, and rekindle their spirits. Many things will try to stop you, but you must overcome them. There are no weapons in this game, only cunning and, more importantly, kindness.

Some of the dialogue is simply crushing. The smallest acts of generosity are met with shock and deep-welling gratitude from these sweet creatures who want nothing more than a kind word, or a kind face in the dark. There are some you can't save. There are some who don't want to be saved. It feels awful to leave them behind, but God knows you can't force healing on people who aren't ready.

The narrator is very sweet-sounding and it's nice to listen to her accented English. Some of the puzzles are easy and some are randomly really hard, but they are mostly enjoyable. Most of all, I REALLY wish there was a map.

Overall, this game settles into a category I would call "bittersweet but hopeful" and I really am enjoying it. I think it's something really special to say that kindness is both powerful and contagious. The world is cruel, but people don't have to be.

But honestly though, even with that last one it's fairly easy to get yourself unstuck just by running around, and the rest really are just minor nitpicks.

130742748.review:
[h1][url=store.steampowered.com/app/990630/The_Last_Campfire/]The Last Campfire[/url] is an outstanding little gem with magnificent ambiance and an uplifting, hopeful narrative.[/h1]

Rescue forlorn Embers and guide them back to the campfire by solving amusing and clever puzzles, all relatively easy challenges, with a few simple mechanics and good use of the environment. No death, no fail state, no pressure, just relaxing exploration and puzzle solving. Everything is fully thought-out. Simple intuitive controls make it a charm to use.

Powerful narration and expressive characters, adorable in their simplicity, and beautiful mysterious environments easily bring this harmonious world to life. Though not without some level of sadness, it all leads to a rewarding, positive ending. A single pleasant voice narrates the entire story, including all characters, making it very personal.

Excellent soundtrack and art direction are a perfect fit for the style.

Pages of the Wanderer's Diary can be found in slightly remote or partially hidden locations, sometimes in plain sight. These optional collectibles provide additional story elements, though I am never a fan of this storytelling method due to the inability to easily track missed pages. One can always replay chapters to find them, but this breaks the instantaneity of the story flow.

The Last Campfire feels genuine and wholesome. It is easy to recommend.

I bought this game with a discount and paid less than 5$. I think the regular price might be a little bit high, considering how short the game is, but it was more than enough for the money I spent. 

I like puzzles and cute graphics, so I did not think much when buying this game and I am really glad it found its way to my Steam library. 

The story is simple, yet very touching and although I did not spend too much time with the main character, I felt somehow connected with it. The Last Campfire is about journey, about dealing with a loss and the importance of hope. It was really easy for me to immerse in the story. 

The puzzles were fun and not too frustrating, so I've had a lot of fun with them as well. 

Overall, I would recommend this game to anyone who would like to embark on a melancholic, atmospheric journey in a pretty world full of interesting creatures and fun puzzles. For me, it was a great experience and I'd love to be able to forget this game, just to play it for the first time again.

129776923.review:
[code]Puedes ver más reseñas como esta en la mentoría [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/34129733/][u]PIXEL 404[/u][/url][/code]

[h1]La esperanza es lo último que se pierde[/h1]
Hello Games, famosa por todo el asunto de No Man’s Sky y luego saber redimirse a base de esfuerzo y trabajo, sacó esta pequeña joya entre actualización y actualización de su gran proyecto, y el resultado es simplemente magnífico.

En ella controlaremos a un pequeño ser, el cual rema por un río junto con los suyos hasta que pierde su remo y acaba varado en un lugar totalmente diferente. A partir de ahí, y lleno de miedo, iniciará un periplo que le deparará muchas sorpresas, y no solo al personaje sino también a nosotros mismos.

[h1]La alegoría como recurso permanente[/h1]
No pasará mucho tiempo hasta que nos demos cuenta que The Last Campfire no es más que una extraordinaria alegoría de la vida misma por la que todos transitamos. Nuestro personaje, Ember, se irá topando con otros como él, pero algunos estarán convertidos en piedra porque han perdido las ganas de vivir, la esperanza y ese impulso vital que nos mueve a todos.

Nuestra labor será entrar dentro de ellos, puzle mediante, y encontrar esa ascua de esperanza que aún arde en su interior para devolverle las ganas de vivir y animarles a continuar su camino. No por nada, el juego llama a estos personajes “almas en pena”.

Básicamente, este es el objetivo del juego, todo ello mientras vamos avanzando por los escenarios buscando un modo de hallar el río para volverlo a retomar. ¿Pero no es el camino realmente lo importante en el viaje? Sin duda, The Last Campfire tiene unas intenciones narrativas mucho más profundas de lo que a priori se podría esbozar en un primer vistazo, y lo hace todo de manera notable.

Durante la aventura nos encontraremos con personajes fascinantes y muy peculiares, y algunos de ellos nos pedirán ciertas cosas para poder seguir avanzando, con puzles o buscando objetos. Esto es todo un acierto, porque se nos muestra que nuestro personaje es realmente un recién llegado, y que allí ya pasaban muchas cosas antes de que él llegara. Todo ello ayuda a crear una narrativa muy entretenida y realmente profunda si sabes de qué se está hablando en cada momento.

[h1]Puzles por doquier, y todos muy entretenidos[/h1]
Aparte de la exploración y el descubrimiento de hojas de diarios que nos cuentan una historia que nos meten en situación, el juego tira del recurso del puzle casi permanentemente. Pero no desesperes, no son del tipo de puzles que acabas cansado o aburrido, ya sea por su simpleza o por su alta dificultad. Ni mucho menos.

Mover bloques, girar manivelas, encender fuegos, iluminar estancias y otra serie de puzles ingeniosos son los que poblaran el lugar. Es un tanto complicado plasmar lo entretenido que son los puzles sin contar cómo son, pero es mejor que los descubras personalmente para que te sorprendas y te diviertas a partes iguales. Salve decir que nunca te aburrirás de ellos y que solo estarás deseando encontrar más durante el viaje.

[h1]No solo es profundo y entretenido, también es muy bonito[/h1]
Aparte de lo anteriormente comentado, The Last Campfire ofrece unos gráficos bastante bonitos con unas animaciones muy bien hechas y graciosas. Ver al personaje principal moverse es todo un espectáculo, porque es gracioso y enternecedor en todo momento. Además, todo es muy colorido, y siempre ofrece escenarios novedosos durante toda la aventura.

A esto hay que sumarle la voz de la narradora, la cual nos irá acompañando y contándonoslo todo durante el periplo con una voz muy dulce que enriquece bastante la experiencia global.

[h1]Conclusiones[/h1]
Por todo lo comentado, y por más cosas que mejor que las descubras tú mismo, The Last Campfire se descubre como una experiencia tremendamente enriquecedora, ya que aporta un mensaje profundo y una jugabilidad realmente entretenida. Toda una joya.

129495081.review:
[b]Sights & Sounds[/b]
- The graphics are cartoonish and 3D. Not a visual powerhouse by any means, but still looks nice
- The music was fine, but I didn't find myself humming along
- The voice acting was serviceable

[b]Story & Vibes[/b]
- Without spoiling anything important, you play as a little being named Ember who wants to help other little beings make their way to the end of a mysterious set of caves to find rest
- It's a sparse story with few plot points, but a definitive narrative isn't really the focus
- The game focuses much more on the philosophical tapestry you weave together yourself from your brief encounters with strangers and the journal scraps you find along the way
- The mood is pensive and mysterious, and rarely strays from that throughout its length

[b]Playability & Replayability[/b]
- The game takes place around 3 main environments, each with a central hub with a campfire in it. Your goal is to help guide some requisite number of lost souls move on before you're able to progress
- Each so-called "forlorn" you encounter transports you to a puzzle you must solve to save them. Some are surprisingly easy, while others take a bit of trial and error. Some of the tough ones are pretty cool
- It's not horribly difficult to 100% this game (just rescue all the forlorn), so many players may find a lack of motivation to replay it

[b]Overall Impressions & Performance[/b]
- The game ran flawlessly on the Steam Deck
- I ran into a bug where I actually squished and trapped myself with a column. Quitting out and loading back in fixed it

[b]Final Verdict[/b]
- [b]7/10[/b]. If you like the idea of going from puzzle to puzzle while a bittersweet little story plays out in the interludes, this is a pretty worthwhile experience

129485921.review: Overall a really great game. Puzzles had different levels of difficulty and the world itself is very imaginative. 129475505.review:
A pretty good game, if not an excellent one. 

The positives: it's pretty, charming, cute, relaxing, briskly paced, and generally has neat puzzles that are fun to solve. I particularly liked the use of on-rails cameras, which leads to some really fun environmental foreshadowing in the foreground/background. 

The negatives: the fairy-tale concept and narration kind of grow old by the end, the plot (insofar there is one) is weak, and the game generally sort of lacks surprises.  I liked what this was going for, thematically, but there is no real depth or progression beyond what you get within the first hour, which was disappointing.  It would have been nice to have more unique characters with specific backgrounds and troubles, rather than mostly generic NPCs that have quite generic struggles. 

Despite that list of negatives, i'd still say this is a good game that is worth playing. It's just seems like it could have been great were it to have more depth and ideas.

129469421.review: A lovely little puzzle game about taking a journey into the unknown, accepting your emotions (anger, pain, loss, regret, etc.) and accepting the end. i don't usually make reviews but for this one i will.

the graphics are wonderful and imo, pretty immersive as it is. the sound and music are very chill and comfortable. as for game play, i'd say it's simple that it doesn't break the flow of things. for people who aren't used to puzzles, it can get pretty tricky but i would say they won't frustrate anyone too much. as someone who likes puzzles, solving the puzzle was pretty instinctive though so i was able to focus on the story.

the story is great and the narration just fits so perfectly well, rounding up the entire game as an experience. the game touches on meaning, hope, and hopelessness in a way that can get a little personal but not too on the nose that you'd scoff at it.

the game is "short" apparently can be played for 3 hours but i played it for 6 hours, so that sounds worth it. so anyway i might have cried a hell lot after i finished the game. thanks for the tears, i had a good time.

128277412.review:
This game is quite a little gem - no wonder the devs are not afraid to share a demo :D Beautiful visuals, incredible atmosphere, and a story that's more emotional than rational, yet very captivating.
The gameplay itself is a mix of exploration and environment puzzles. The exploration is very enjoyable, thanks to the excellent visual design, and the game is careful to ensure it doesn't get overly lengthy (and thus, boring). The puzzles are interesting and generally satisfying, although not very difficult - they serve as a slightly cerebral counterpoint to the otherwise very emotional nature of the game. This mix works quite well together - and at 6-7 hours, it's the right length, there's always enough fresh stuff to keep the player interested.
When people debate that video games are an art form, The Last Campfire is an excellent example. Very much recommended.

128276130.review: The Last Campfire is a 7-10 hr adventure puzzle game whose main focus is on the story and puzzles. It is quite linear and the puzzles are quite easy to solve. Yet, the story and the overall cuteness of the game can hook to finish it. I thoroughly enjoyed it from a story perspective. If you enjoy puzzle games, don't give this a miss. This is made by the team behind No Man's Sky.

IDK if I recommend it or not.

It's quite charming at times. It runs well. The puzzles are fairly varied. But it's also rarely challenging and very slow.

While it lets you backtrack to see if you missed anything or if anyone reacted to changes, it never rewards doing so. Dialog doesn't change even when the character was talking about a level-changing problem which you have since solved; their lines don't change and they act like nothing happened, which makes the game world feel very static. (OTOH, it signals that there's no reason to waste time on such things... but then why does it let you walk all the way back to the start of the game, and then if you do that it makes you spend ages getting back to where you were!?)

There's a surprising amount of voiced lines for what seems to be a low-budget side-project, and the narrator does a good job. But I also found myself losing interest in the story and audio/text logs that you find. I just wanted to do the puzzles, not listen to more. While the story is wholesome and sincere and about a deep concept, it also doesn't actually have that much depth, and TBH I kept zoning out.

I don't regret playing through itm but IDK if it was the best way to spend that time either.

It might be good for young children, who might find the puzzles more challenging. Maybe I am not the target audience here?

So, is it good or bad? Well, as a decider, it was Epic exclusive for a year, and that taint is inescapable. It's maybe one of the least-bad Epic-exclusive games I've taken a gamble on, knowing the developers thought it made more sense to take Tim Sweeney's money than to risk going to the actual market, but that's a very low bar as most of those games are absolutely atrocious let-downs.

There are better puzzle games to play than this, but if you have young children, they might enjoy it a lot.

[h1] Purchased through the Healing Puzzles bundle on Steam during Autumn Sale of 2022. Well worth the price regardless. [/h1]
[b]PROS[/b]
+ Fun Puzzles that never go beyond too complex or long

+ Cute art style and graphics are pleasing

+ World is linear and straight forward to navigate[spoiler]not counting optional Wanderer's chests[/spoiler]

127591616.review:
[h1]It's good[/h1]

This is a very good little puzzle game with simple yet touching story. Not much to say about it so i'll probably keep this extremely short.

Gameplay is very simple – you run around solving puzzles. You get few huge areas to explore and a bunch of collectibles to find. Each area has sub-areas with its own puzzles, characters or quests. The story is told without words.
The main focus here is obviously puzzles which are mostly different and require different approach. But none of them are too hard so don't worry, you won't get frustrated, you'll have fun.
On top of that you're presented with a very nice heartwarming story and melancholic atmosphere so you want to progress further to unveil the whole story and see how it ends.
It's also a very chill and relaxing game, there's no pressure, you can just sit back, relax and enjoy.

Graphics are very cute and the game in general looks wonderful. Performance obviously is great and it has ultrawide support.

Sound design also is good and adds to the overall atmosphere.

Get this on sale, it's worth it.

[b]Pros[/b]
[list]
[*]Good puzzles
[*]Good story
[*]Good sound
[*]Ultrawide support
[*]Chill
[/list]
[b]Cons[/b]
[list]
[*]I don't even know
[/list]
