125218028.review:
[h1] Puzzled About Loss, Death, and Despair [/h1]

The Last Campfire is a beautiful puzzle adventure game with cuddly looks, but a very deep theme about loss, death and despair. If you like  games that make your brain hurt with their puzzles like Forgotten Anne, Sonority or Ori and the Blind Forest, you might like The Last Campfire, too.

[hr][/hr]

[b] Pros [/b]
+Well done score that is subtle, but still gives you goosebumps at the right moments
+Well thought out puzzles with different levels of difficulty
+Intriguing writing, that will make you wonder what all of that even means
+Cuddly, sweet art style with creepy or weird splotches from time to time
+Great pacing, that let's you have breaks and keeps you hooked at the same time

[b] Cons [/b]
-it's very short
-the meaningfullness of all the messages, settings, and dialogue might seem a little over the top, if you are not willing to engage
-an overview map of the world is missing. And that is a big deal! And also the run button has to be pushed again once you switch screens (why?!!!)

[hr][/hr]

Rating for gamers: [b] 8/10 [/b]

125205899.review:
There is not a lot to spoil on this game I think, but still I felt good going in mostly blind. The gameplay itself is really nice. Interesting puzzles, lots of variations on ideas and mechanics. These vary from pretty obvious to more challenging, and at least for me none were particularly frustrating. 

One thing I was really impressed by is how the game has a story to tell, but it mostly doesn't slow you down to tell it. The narration will play even as you close a message. This lets you move towards your next task while taking in the story. It is easy for this sort of choice to go unseen because it is elegant and well executed.

Another impressive choice for me, was seeing additional story hidden around the world. You can get the core story without these. But for those who explore and want to find everything, this is what turns up. The richness of this story made seeking out all these little notes rewarding. Instead of grinding out secret little trinkets like most games, here you truly are rewarded for nosing around a little longer.

Because of how well executed the gameplay is, it seems simple and intuitive throughout. That is important because it stands aside and lets the story shine, and this story does. It is thoughtful and melancholy, bittersweet and engaging. Some stories rely very much on the plot, some hang thinly on [i] v i b e s[/i]. The Last Campfire deftly navigates tone and content, coming out stronger for it and very affecting as well. Most of the NPCs get only a sentence or two, and a great many of them stopped me a moment to reflect on their story and my own. That is a triumph for any medium.

Absolutely worth your time and money to play this game.

124622748.review:
The Last Campfire was actually intended as a Pile Of Shame purchase, after Hello Games has been bringing updates and expeditions into No Man's Sky at no cost for years, which other publishers would have packaged into DLCs. Then Steam Deck arrived and I installed it as an easy to use title to get used to the device. After a little over 5 hours of play (Steam presumably doesn't count time without an internet connection) I had it finished including all the Achievements. 

It's a fantastic mix of clever but quite easy puzzles, cute graphics and a beautifully told story, making Ember's journey a real pleasure. Together with the sense for the style of a children's fairy tale, these parts add up to a recommendable result, filled with themes that are close to all of us and not really just set in a faraway world. Inspired by the Brothers Grimm, among others, real-life problems are addressed in a fantastic way. Adult themes, for example concerning fears and loss, are cleverly packaged in an easily digestible way without resorting to violence at any time.

It's a tiny world compared to NMS, but one that can be enjoyed by all. A puzzle adventure without any grind elements, with an emotionally touching story and consistently entertaining tasks.

124315836.review:
The Last Campfire is a puzzle game, where you play as a creature known as Ember who tries to complete their journey, and help fellow embers along the way. I tried this game because people say its similar to Lost Words: Beyond the Page, and its true. The overall vibe and atmosphere of both games are alike, the difference is that LW: BtP's levels are more linear, 2D-ish, and with some platforming parts. TLC is 3D, has levels you can roam freely (usually around a hub area) and focuses more on puzzles, with no platforming as you cannot jump.

The gameplay focuses on exploration and puzzles. There are hub areas, named Campfires, where to progress you must save several forlorn souls. They're usually in side areas near the hub. You don't have to save them all to progress, but you better do. To reach a forlorn you sometimes need to explore or solve a puzzle, but the real puzzle begins when you enter their head. Each forlorn has a unique "puzzle room" for you to solve. The puzzles range from very easy to a bit confusing, but nothing too difficult. If you missed a forlorn, don't worry as you can backtrack to previous areas.

The puzzle is basically to create a path to their soul, either by activating levers, moving heavy objects with your Lanthorn, reflect lights, etc. A good feature the devs made is that the solved puzzles can be played straight from the menu, with some bonus ones. It's nice to be able to replay puzzles without going through the whole game again, but the only ones available are the forlorn puzzles, not the ones you encounter in the "real" world.

Lastly, the game has a pretty meaningful message, like how sometimes, if not most times, the journey and helping others along the way are more important than the goal itself. It's kinda deep and touching, but not really sad, rather heartwarming I think. If you love puzzle games, or ones with cute aesthetics, give The Last Campfire a try. We need more of those "cute-but-kinda-bittersweet-puzzle-games", like this and Lost Words.

124315700.review:
[b]My Playtime:[/b] 5:02:34 (100% achievement, finished the game)
[b]Grindy Achievement(s):[/b] No.
[b]Optional Achievement(s):[/b] No.
[b]Difficult Achievement(s):[/b] No.

[h1]Intro[/h1]
[b]The Last Campfire[/b] is a puzzle game about a creature called Ember, which is trying to save their kind that has turned to stone. The journey isn't that simple, though. You need to solve puzzles on your way to reach them.

[b]Pros:[/b]
- 25 puzzles with varied mechanics
- Collectibles have markers for easier tracking

[b]Cons:[/b]
- Unable to skip animations
- It's hard to distinguish between climbing stairs and paddling a boat since they use the same button

[b]Specs[/b]
Intel Core i5-9300H 2.40GHz, 8GB RAM, NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1650

[h1]Should you buy this game?[/h1]
[b]Yes.[/b]
[i]If you like cute-looking visuals and simple puzzles, buy this game.[/i]

[hr][/hr]
[h1]In-Depth Review[/h1]

[h3]Visuals[/h3]
Most areas look simple, but the presentation makes it seem that they don't. Decorations, crumbled walls, and fogs help to obscure the areas, hiding hidden paths to collectibles and making the area look more gorgeous and vast. It's still easy to traverse the area and find your way through, and the marking that shows when you are near interactable objects does a good job to distinguish it from the decorations.

[h3]Story[/h3]
The story was told like in a children's book, albeit with more difficult words. It tries to tell the story in poems and short words, and sometimes it can be hard to understand what was being told because of it. The voice actor does a good job with it, though. The voice sounds soothing and mysterious at the same time, while still trying to be distinct whenever another person is talking.

[h3]The Game[/h3]
[b]Gameplay[/b]
[b]The Last Campfire[/b] has two kinds of puzzles. One is where you need to explore your surroundings to unlock new areas and another where you have to go to a closed space and solve puzzles to save another Ember. The first one is easier since it serves as a warm-up before you get to the juicy part, and although some of the second kind of puzzles will require you to exercise your brain, they are still easy to solve.

The exploration puzzles require you to remember your surroundings. The most that they can do is to trick your eyes, as they have hidden areas and secrets that conceal collectibles. You need to remember where you need to use objects, the puzzle mechanics, as well as all abilities that you have to uncover everything. Although it might look simple, there were times when I didn't realize that I can do things and stumped for a while.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2875667034 

Puzzles are unique. All puzzles might look similar at first glance, but they usually have a different focus. One might require you to push a box to a certain spot, another might want you to fiddle with switches. The variance help to make the puzzles not boring, and although some are reused, they are usually positioned far from each other. Some of them also can be brute-forced, and others might require you to think outside the box.

[b]Length and Difficulty[/b]
The in-game clock says that I finished the game at 5:02:34. I did get everything, from saving all Embers and obtaining all of the collectibles. As I said before, the game is easy to beat. There might be puzzles that can leave you stumped, but it's mostly because you need to rethink your approach and try other things. Brute forcing might be helpful in some puzzles, but not without having an idea of what to do beforehand. As for collectibles, they are still easy to track as long as you know what to do. The game also has a counter for the collectible in each area for easier tracking.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2863769604 

[b]Issues[/b]
Although the game looks beautiful, it can be boring to see the same animations over and over again, especially when you are doing a puzzle that is required to save the Embers. The game will usually show the same animation after you finished the puzzle with a minor change based on the one that you saved. Despite that, it doesn't allow you to skip the animations.

There is also no restart button, so you need to revisit the area and have to see the opening animation again every time you reenter the puzzle room. Lastly, the game tends to fail to distinguish between paddling a boat and climbing a ladder. Both actions use the same button and you will encounter them in a lot of areas.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
[b]The Last Campfire[/b] is a puzzle game for casual players. The short playtime and easy difficulty are perfect for its target audience, and the cute-looking creature help to increase its charm. The atmosphere that the game has also helped you to relax, and with how small each area is, it's easy to finish everything without missing out. It's a cute, charming little game that will leave your heart melting with its presentations.

124294655.review:
A hauntingly beautiful game that guarantees self and outside reflection to others.

Playing as a dying Ember you follow the path through purgatory where others have "lost" their way, solving simple to complex puzzles to aid those to find their flame that once left their soul and guiding them to the End. It begs the question how you and others perceive death with some Embers not wishing to be saved with conflicting and heartbreaking dialogue resulting in the reminder that "Not all problems are puzzles to be solved."

Each level offers a variety of fun and creative characters from the lonely Fisherman, Giant Frog, Bird King and Giant Pig. A welcoming linear guidance to the next chapters of the story line and a comic relief in the face of a haunting theme.

The puzzles are fantastic and short which I prefer in games, not overly complex but with no help some can be tricky if you're not a logical thinker. Reminiscent of M.C.Escher the puzzles are a surreal disposition to solve the issues within a dying Embers mind without breaking the immersion of the overall environment. 

Lastly, Rachel August's Icelandic narration throughout the game is outstanding, her grace and joy seeps through every line of script with ease.

124250140.review:
The Last Campfire is a short puzzle game that follows Ember, a humanoid 'sock puppet' creature on their quest to restore the light to a hopeless world. It's a game with a lot of heart, but some frustrations that really hurt the experience.

Let's start with the good. The ambience, aesthetic, and narrator work perfectly to bring to life the game. The art team did an incredible job, with everything from the innocence to the voiceover's accent bringing a sense of wonder and innocence that makes the game one of the best artistic pieces out there. I cannot express just how great the soundtrack, the narrator, and the colour palette are.

There's a lot of variety in gameplay. From moving blocks in specific patterns, to traversing water with a boat, and directing animals to certain locations. Every area felt different and I felt the game got stronger as time went on and new mechanics were added.

The thing that's hurting this game is how it communicates to you. I struggled a lot at the start, always being unsure of what I could do, where I could go, and ultimately how I can progress. Once I figured out that the game is structured in such a way that you have to bring pieces between areas to solve puzzles or find items in different locations the experience got a whole lot better. Maybe this is on me, but I do feel like there is a pretty big hurdle in the early game after you find the Forest Campfire.

I definitely recommend this game despite this, especially those who want something with a great hopeful vibe to it.

Pros:
+ Atmosphere. The ambience is fantastic.
+ Soundtrack. Gorgeous with a great variety.
+ Narrator. Fantastic performance.
+ Variety in Gameplay. For a short game, there was a lot of variety in the puzzles.

Cons:
- Game Design. Confusing at points.
- Game is too short.

Overall, definitely worth playing if you want a short puzzle game with great atmosphere. 7/10.

122418932.review:
I did not solve all the puzzles, because in the end it was a drag to play, even though I only played it for 4 hours.

This is one of those games that are "artsy" and therefore "good". Those games always have some kind "deeper meaning". In order to make the player see the deeper meaning, no matter how dense they are, the game forces the player's hand a lot. You can't change the view because the nice looking level design has to be viewed perfectly the way the developers intended you to view it. You can't run or jump because you're supposed to take your time walking from A to B and jumping would take from the atmosphere the game forces on you. The graphics are okay. Nice to look at from a distance, but after 10 minutes you have seen the lot. You can't turn off the whispering woman's voice narrating every single piece of information and frankly it discomforted me a lot.

The puzzles themselves are not ground-breaking. They're using existing puzzle mechanics and spice them up with an additional caveat here and there. Most of the time you already know what you have to do and it just takes "ages" to do it (this is not a real puzzle in the game, but "Walking from A to B" is simple, but if you gotta walk for 5 minutes it takes time. If you solve a puzzle with one look but have to move x pieces into the right position and you can't speed this up, then it's simple but still takes time). The other times you're not viewing the whole thing as one puzzle but just do "the next step" (because there is just one, obvious next step) and you also arrive at the solution.

So if you like artsy games that you don't have to think about too much, and you just want to chill for an hour and then go to bed, play this. From a gamer / gameplay perspective, this game is a drag.

122411117.review: I loved the easy pace of this game and it was a really relaxing experience. The voice narration was perfect and really added to the overall feel of the game. Ember was so cute! 122381729.review:
Agradezco enormemente haberme adentrado en el mundo de The Last Camfire. El juego usa una narrativa suave y acogedora para llevarte por una historia de reflexión personal lleva de metáforas tan sencillas como complejas de entender y aceptar como la vida misma. 

Los puzzles tienen una complejidad idónea. No son excesivamente difíciles. En los más rebuscados puedes estar unos 20 minutos como mucho. El diseño de los escenarios y los personajes es extremadamente relajante. Hasta la forma de andar y portar objetos del protagonista reconforta. Un punto bastante fuerte es lo buena que es la narrativa de la historia y la espectacular voz de la narradora en inglés que te lleva por todo el juego. 

Es una joya. Corto e intenso. Acogedor y relajante. Lo he estado jugando en una semana donde mi salud mental no ha estado en su punto más alto y debo decir, de corazón, que era siempre un momento de alivio y paz poder continuar con la historia.

121755693.review:
The store page blurb is a great summary. In my words, "A saccharine yet charming story commenting on the human response to hope and despair, taking the form of an easy puzzle game." This will appeal more to people interested in sentimental storytelling and 2010's-indie-developer aesthetics, moreso than to avid puzzle game fanatics. A laid-back experience perfect for cozy, upcoming fall and winter days. The phrase "baby's first Outer Wilds" captures my perception of this game.

Three things I liked:
1) Puzzle mechanics were unique and easy to learn (good sign-posting/discoverability).
2) Challenges and mechanics build progressively.
3) Pleasant story and art style.

Three possible improvements:
1) Puzzles were not difficult - I finished the main game in <6 hours and only had to restart two of the puzzles (this might be subjective based on one's experience with puzzles).
2) Short game - 6 hours of main content and a handful of bonus puzzles upon completion felt short, especially since I did not find the puzzles particularly challenging.
3) More story development - It was difficult to gauge progress from the story beats. I had to be told "Oh you're going to the final area next, then your journey will be over." The story felt more like a string of isolated concepts than a tale progressed by my actions.

121608941.review:
I stumbled across this game on a sale and it was quite the surprise. The colors and graphics were soft and inviting, the controls were simple, and the puzzles were just challenging enough to hold my interest.

The Last Campfire sees you playing as a being known as Ember. They awaken in a cave and see that they must make a journey home. Along the way they meet other embers and characters who have lost hope in the journey or in life itself. It's up to Ember to save them and lead them home, wherever that may be.

The Last Campfire is a simple puzzle platformer. You won't be jumping or fighting enemies, rather you will moving blocks and manipulating objects to solve puzzles. In the main world, you can explore, find items, and beings called Forlorn. They are embers who have lost and have turned to stone. Once you interact with them, you will transported to a puzzle stage in which you have to move or manipulate objects to reach the goal and save them. Each world you go to has a set amount of Forlorn you must free to continue on and reach the end.

The game has great graphics, nice use of colors, and great narration to keep you interested in the story. The whole thing has a storybook kinda vibe and I totally dig it. The best part is that it's not a terribly long game. You can extend it a bit by looking for collectibles from a being known as The Wanderer. They are not necessary to get %100, but still fun to find.

I think my only gripe with this game is simple. With puzzle games like this, it's almost necessary to have some kind of hint system in place for your puzzles. This game does not have that. Most of the puzzles were simple to solve and may need a few more brain cells than normal to solve, but some of the later puzzles really had me stumped and I had to look up videos just to help guide me in the right direction.

Final verdict? This was a fantastic little game. I loved the vibe, the story, and the puzzles had a great "Ah Ha!" feel to them at times which always feels good. If you're looking for calm and chillaxful puzzle game to play, The Last Campfire might be what you're looking for. Thanks for reading!

121603659.review:
I chose to play this game after hearing about the triumphant story of Hello Games and Sean Murray, one of the founders of the company. The game looked cute and relaxing so I wasn't expecting much about the game itself.
This game unfolds a story that is very close to ours, but it does so by gently and carefully handling it. Fears we have, worries we ponder about, regrets we bear... all the things we isolate to be a forlorn. There are no answers to those, but the story convinces that we move forward regardless. It's a typical "lesson" anyone might can give, but not as uniquely as this game does. 

Give it a go, and see if you resonate with the story! Whether you do or don't, it is still a great piece for a puzzle game. Though they are not particularly difficult, it does have enough volume to be entertaining.
P.S: You don't have to scavenge hunt for those "forgotten things" as they do not have achievement linked to them - they are great reads though. Plus, they will give you the better grasp of the ending!

121469663.review:
[h1] Cute little adventure puzzle game [/h1]

This is a short and cute puzzle game which plays like an old Zelda game. You solve puzzles, you pass by blocked segments, you solve puzzles, you get an item that unblocks new parts of the game or provide you new gameplay and keep solving puzzles. 
The puzzles are not too hard even though some can be a bit tricky. There is no hint system but you can always try another puzzle. There are also puzzles in the world itself which gives you small bits of lore.

The story is pretty simple but the characters and the environment are very well done and lovable.

It's very easy to suggest this game if you enjoy Zelda-like games with simple puzzles and exploring. It's very straightforward and doesn't require much backtracking which is a nice plus.. It doesn't try to inflate the game time with useless walking trips.

121440568.review:
The Last Campfire es un juego indie que tanto en su apartado artístico y sonora es una delicia. El juego te pondrá en la piel de Ember, una pequeña ascua que tendrá que salvar a otras ascuas perdidas a través de puzzles lógicos. Estos son sencillos realmente y cuanto más se acerca el final del juego son un pelín más complicados pero nada del otro mundo.

En cuanto a su historia no es su punto fuerte, pero quizás lo importante es más el mensaje que toca temas tan trascendentales como la aceptación de nosotros mismos y el sentido de nuestra propia existencia. También es una oda a la esperanza, esa pequeña "ascua" que albergamos dentro de cada uno y que no debemos dejar que se apague, ni en nuestros momentos más oscuros.

La experiencia es agradable en conjunto, aunque un tanto corta (~4 h), debido en parte a su linealidad y a su escasa capacidad de investigación del entorno. Hay algún que otro pequeño bug pero nada importante.

Si te gustan los juegos indies, de puzzles sencillos y con una atmósfera relajante, The Last Campfire te gustará!

121416183.review:
This review is specially made for those who like to get all the achievements in games (minor spoilers ahead).

[b]Description:[/b]  
The Last Campfire is a short indie adventure and puzzle game where you control a small creature called ember, similar to a Jawa Jawa from SW but cuter and with bright colors, that has to save other creatures from their species by solving puzzles.
The story is interesting and well narrated and the environments, NPCs and objects are highly detailed and with vibrant colors and are very distinct from each other. 
The puzzles you have to solve have a lot of variety and several different mechanics, that you have to use both in the open world as in each puzzle's individual location, but all of them are easy to solve for an adult, so I’d guess the game is mostly targeted at children.

[b]Achievements:[/b]  
[b]How many:[/b] 22 Achievements.
[b]How much time:[/b] Around 5 hours.
[b]Game difficulty:[/b] Easy, the puzzles are simple to solve.   
[b]Achievements’ Difficulty:[/b] Easy. Saving all the creatures will grant you all the achievements.

[b]Overall opinion:[/b]  
The Last Campfire is a beautiful but short adventure puzzle game, with puzzles that a child can solve but that might feel too easy for an adult. Still, definitely recommended.


[b]Join and follow my group Ribbon Hunters for more suggestions and reviews of easy indie games to get all the achievements: https://store.steampowered.com/curator/42556190-Ribbon-Hunters/ [/b]

i really enjoyed this game! it was quite short, it took me around 6.5 hours to complete, and the puzzles were not to challenging. i love how new mechanics are introduced throughout the game, and they are merged very well with the mechanics from the earlier stages of the game - it makes the puzzles feel quite intricate, often made me feel ''nostalgic'' in a way, thinking like ''oooh i remember this''....
i'm seeing a couple reviews that say they dont like the voice acting, but i personally loved it! the actress sounds so charming, with a soft accent that i can't quite decipher - sounds either french or scandinavian-rooted to me, and i believe it enhanced the game experience for me because it did feel like i was experiencing another world that was translated to me in a way. throughout the game, there are hidden stone ''boxes'' that have pieces of lore descriptions inside, and when you open one, the actress will say ''[character name] found a scrap of journal'' and idk theres just something so charming and sweeet about the way she says ''scrap of journal'', im obsessed with it haha
nothing bad to say about the game! i think the story is a bit convoluted and mysterious, its not really explained in the end, but i guess its all up to interpretation, especially considering that there are some obvious motifs relating to mental health topics, so i think its good that the story is up to interpretation because everyone experiences mental health in a different way.
all in all, a wonderful game! i would recommend c:

120789971.review:
This is a beautifully designed game with a deeper meaning that requires a bit of reading in between the lines. On the outside, you play as a cute little character that progresses through a story while solving puzzles that make you think, but aren't too challenging. The real underlining beauty of this game is that it tackles the issue of mental health in a way that not many games have. Throughout this journey, there are many analogies that help you empathise with people that are struggling mentally in their day-to-day life. It shows what they're going through, and what thoughts surround their head as they feel stuck and hopeless. Yet this game beautifully displays that there is always hope, and choosing a path that is scary and uncertain to go down is better, although harder, than staying stuck and feeling nested. I highly recommend this game. 

Hello Games did a fantastic job, and it's pretty cheap for a worthwhile journey.

The game is gorgeous if you're into that kind of art style.
That is all the positive things I can say for this game.

Gameplay-wise, the game feels like a chore to play after a while. The puzzle felt repetitive and uninventive, it only revolves around permutating the movements of the objects using specific order or directions to solve it. That is it for most of the time.
On top of that, too many invisible walls and flawed game logics. Just because the floors are 1 inches higher or lower, your characters cannot walk through it. I mean, come on!!!
Also the outdated distracting journal scavenging, it is a 2021 game, ppl should come up with better implementation for side-story notes instead of treating it like a meaningless note collecting mission that tortures the minds with OCD and ADHD. It doesn't even feel rewarding to collect them all, it even breaks the immersion at times.

Story-wise, I'm quite neutral. I dont hate nor do I love it. But I wont call it story that much since it is more like poetry.

120004029.review: I expect for a lot of people that the narrator is hit or miss. For those that don't know, there is a female narrator that narrates the entire game, what NPCs say, how you feel, what things are, etc. These bleeds into the philosophy of "show, don't tell" in games, and the narrator can step over this boundary sometimes, including telling you how the protagonist feels, which should largely be up to the player in my opinion. In the beginning, I was very disappointed about the narrator being there to begin with, and talking as much as she did, largely because I'm not used to have someone narrate the entire playthrough of any puzzle adventure game I've played. With that said, this narrator grew on me a lot as I played the game, and she speaks in a very "story time-esc" way. After finishing the game, the narrator is maybe one of the most memorable parts of the game, and I'm really glad I played it. However, I still wouldn't be surprised if others wouldn't like this element of the game.

Para resumir: El juego es lindo, corto y sencillo. 
¿Lo recomiendo? Sí.
Equivale más o menos al precio de una tarde de cine y dura bastante más que una película.

Los puzles en general se resuelven casi de manera intuitiva, fáciles de encontrar los coleccionables, mundo colorido y adorable, la trama típica y sencilla, no se me ha buggeado nada ni una sola vez.

Al acabar el juego te quedan unos puzles extras con un poquitítititito más de nivel que los de la historia, pero nada del otro mundo.

No sé si al haberlo jugado traducido al español ha perdido parte del encanto la narrativa. De hecho, en algunos puntos, lo escrito no decía lo mismo que lo narrado, pero no por adaptar y que se entendiera mejor, si no porque sí lo simplificaban mucho más en español y perdía chicha. Además las notas "secretas" en español no rimaban y en inglés sí :C

Es como un cuento infantil interactivo. [spoiler] No estoy seguro de qué querían transmitir, porque parece que debe ser una sensación agridulce sobre la aceptación de la muerte, del cambio, de superación de etapas, lo malo de la sobreprotección, pero a mi personalmente no me ha transmitido demasiado fuerte ninguno de esos conceptos y eso que soy un "aspersor" de lágrimas con las historias tristes. Pero puede funcionar para dar pinceladas de valores buenos a un público más pequeño. [/spoiler] Aunque pierda un poquito el sentido al traducirse. Pero todo sea dicho, la traducción no era de Google Translate, está hecha con bastante cariño.

En fin. Creo que yo lo pillé de rebajillas, pero aún así si podéis permitiros el precio completo merece la pena :)

118680283.review:
Best puzzle/adventure/exploration game I've played in a while now... particularly because of the story/narrative.

Mechanics wise, this is a 3rd person perspective puzzle game with a familiar mix of puzzles that most gamers are probably familiar with: Moving cubes a certain way, reflecting "lasers" on mirrors the correct angle, activating switches, levers and mechanical systems to achieve your goal.
This is well done and sound for a game by itself... but the thing about The Last Campfire is the story, the adventure itself.
It's both charming, cute and funny, but also profound. In it, you are this little creature called Ember who lost it's way to wherever it was that it was going, and so you need to go through a type of limbo where lots like yourself also ended up in. You will lit campfires along the way, rescue others that are also lost, and open the way for others to follow.

It's all made extra special with the lovely narration and script, turning into a spiritual journey.
I know it might sound a bit sappy from my description, but just trust the reviews, this game is great!
High praise and recommendation!

118621438.review:
I hate doing this, because there is so much I like about this game, but ultimately, The Last Campfire is a better storybook than it is video game. I can't say I was disappointed to have checked it out, as it is only 4-6 hours long (6 hrs if you complete everything, which I did), but I also can't say I can wholeheartedly recommend it.

By far and away the biggest issue is the game's difficulty, or lack thereof. I usually don't knock a game for being easy; not every game has to be hard and I've certainly enjoyed games with nice, relaxing playthroughs. But this one might be the easiest full game I've ever beaten, and uh, I've played a -lot- of games. Technically this is a "puzzle game" but it's hard to call what's in here puzzles; my jar was agape at how simple some of the solutions were. The first hour of this game is one of the worst first impressions I've had with a  game, as the tutorial section drags on way too long for being such a simple game, but truth is the bigger issue is you feel like you're always in a tutorial. It gets slightly, and I mean slightly, more complicated as you go, so you get a bit more engaged, but in the end I don't think a single puzzle took more than 2 minutes to solve, with most solved in 30 seconds or less. I found myself audibly whispering "no way.." under my breath in disbelief every time I ran into yet another puzzle that I couldn't believe actually made it into an otherwise very polished game. I'd say maybe this game is meant for kids, but I know the games I was beating as a kid, and this would have been way too easy for me even then. Don't come in expecting any feeling of accomplishment here; the puzzles are simpler than I am even making sound.

The game is gorgeous, reminding me a lot of Runic Games' 2017 release "Hob," which it borrows much of its style and premise from. That isn't a bad thing, as by far the most enjoyable thing about the game is exploring its overworld and seeing all there is to see. The entire game is narrated storybook-style by a woman with a soft, bespoke accent, which I initially disliked but I grew to appreciate. It isn't "Bastion" levels of quality in narration, but she fits the game quite well. She isn't helped by the writing though, which keeps true to its wondrous, storybook theming throughout, but ends up being quite repetitive. This compounds with the already simple and chore-like nature of the puzzles to make this short playthrough a bit of a drag. I enjoyed exploring the varied environments, and there are actually a lot of unique elements in each area and across the puzzles, but in the end everything is so straightforward it doesn't feel inspired, but more of the same. You go through the game finding and saving lost souls, each of which the narrator gives you very similar sounding lines for. And then you do that 20+ times until the games over. Very often the puzzles are so easy I'm finishing the task before the narrator even finishes her lines.

The story is a central focus but there isn't exactly a plot here. It's more a vibe, and that's fine. A lot of time is spent on trying to fill out a story that can be summarized in a sentence of two, but in the end it does a fair job of giving us the setting, visuals, and environments, which again are all top notch. There are also these optional collectables which are journal entries that are once again rather repetitive; I found my brain turning off as the narrator read off yet another of the 40+ entries hidden throughout the game. I'm not sure they added a lot, as there's just not a whole lot to say, but man it sure tries. Lots of writing to say not very much.

The OST is unintrusive; nothing special but filled with ambiance. Rather forgettable honestly, as you can tell by how few listens it has on Youtube / other platforms outside the game itself. It's not a weakness but certainly not a strength of the game either.

I should mention that there are a handful of bugs here and there (I had one that broke a puzzle on me). The initial cutscene actually broke for me and I had to restart (which certainly didn't help my first impression). Not the best look after Hello Games' notoriously bug-riddled previous game, No Man's Sky, but truthfully the couple bugs I encountered didn't sully the experience too much. There was a handful of frame drops (which shouldn't happen with my monster of a PC), which are apparently far worse on other platforms (Switch, notably). Again, not a big deal, but figured it was worth mentioning.

Overall, The Last Campfire has a ton of charm, with a relaxing, laid-back vibe that is maybe is a bit -too- laid back, verging on boring. It's got an awesome world to explore, and fulfills its mission of being like a children's book in design and feel, but uh forgets to have a game somewhere in the middle. Like I said, there is a -lot- I like about this game, but ultimately it fails the core, most fundamental question that needs to be asked when evaluating a game: "Is it fun?" And uh, not really? It's about as fun as flipping through a children's book and looking at the pretty illustrations and art. But then there's 6 hours of it and for some reason it wants you to complete the simplest puzzles of all time to flip the page. 

Ultimately, the repetitive nature made it hard for me to connect with the game. I don't need it to be a brutally hard puzzle game, but it doesn't even do enough to keep me engaged. If that aspect was different, I'm sure I'd rate this game far higher, but in the end, it's simply not fun.

To be honest, this one positively surprised me in several ways. The presentation looked solid before I bought it, but I didn't expect this game to feel so snappy and fluid. Even the parts where you paddle your little boat feel remarkably quick and controllable.
The puzzles are well designed, not very hard, but satisfying. There's a lot of humor! The more games I play, the more I appreciate a laugh. The Last Campfire delivered.

I think the best about this game is its immaculate pacing and structuring of its progression. I never feel like I'm doing the same thing twice. Tricks are repeated, but don't get stale because they're neatly interwoven with other things to do and explore.

If you like comfy, lighthearted puzzle games with fantastic graphics, music, animation and enjoyable controls, treat yourself to The Last Campfire.

118012074.review:
Such a wonderful little game, a unique story. If I had to briefly describe it? Play it like you'd play Portal 2 - it's a puzzle game with a story element to it. The story is what I'd call "boxed", that is, it's very isolated. The worldbuilding is only present for what the game wants to show the player, the moral is clear, and it's about as clean a cut as you can get.

Overall, the puzzles were very intuitive and used a set of clean, understandable mechanics that put the challenge in arranging simple parts together. The puzzles were fun, and I ended up doing a 100% completion on my first run simply because it felt like the right way to play.

My final verdict is that the game is very worth it. I don't know what average playtime is like, my run lasted just over 5 total hours in two sessions, but I am a very fast puzzle solver and pick up on stuff incredibly easily, so I can't be certain that it will be the same duration for other players. ymmv.

The good:
+ OKish story with slightly better finale
+ Nice puzzle for casual player, although few level are either too easy or too hard if you too focused on specific sequence
+ Nice visual, although character animation feel stiff on few occasion

The bad:
- The exploration of themes is shallow and the game forcing certain emotions

The ugly:
* Narrator voice is ok, but become stale after few hours
* Missing some feature such as key rebind, instant restart on puzzle level and telling when last auto save happened when you quit the game
* Exploration doesn't feel rewarding, you only get short piece of diary which isn't really interesting

It's not bad game, but i'd choose "Not recommend" since Steam doesn't offer "Neutral" option. The Last Campfire isn't great at gameplay or story either. There are lots of game which excel at one of those and few others which excel at both of them.

117149944.review:
This game was visually beautiful, lovely soundtrack, adorable and heart aching story, with fun puzzles to boot. If you want a relaxing game with all the whimsy from your favorite calm games this might be your cup of tea. While my time does say roughly 17 hours, you can beat this game in about 8. I actually walked away for a bit and forgot my computer was still on. I believe this game is worth the price, its a very well loved project that shows the effort that went into it. With my initial thoughts out of the way, here are the pro's and con's.

PROS: 
- Amazingly soothing soundtrack
- Beautiful and captivating aesthetics 
- Wonderful voice acting 
- Cohesive to follow 
- You feel connected to the main character
- You can receive hints that don't just give it all away
- The tasks don't seem redundant or medial 

CONS:
- While this project was very well loved some of the graphics have issues with collision 
- You can't change control keys, and the run button is in an awkward place
- If you "fail" certain puzzles you get restarted to the beginning of the puzzle including the title sequence. 
- The puzzles are almost too easy, taking a minute tops for most of them
- While the voice acting is amazing from the one narrator, I do wish we had a variety of voices for all characters

All in all, if you enjoy calm simple games to pass the time this is for you. However if you want more of a challenge, this might not be the best game to buy.

116785516.review:
From the game's website: "The Last Campfire is an adventure, a story of a lost ember trapped in a puzzling place, searching for meaning and a way home”. I agree, because I've finished the game and I'm still searching for meaning. This game is clearly trying to convey a melancholic tone and tries to make you feel sad because "the ember people around you are sad" with no real explanation. The only deeper meaning to be found in this game is that which the player projects onto the game itself. Otherwise, it feels sad for the sake of being sad, which is no replacement for a more concrete storyline. 
For the most part, the puzzles are very easy. There are a few well-designed ones, but most of the puzzles feel more like speedbumps than anything challenging. 

And apparently a HOT-TAKE: I'm not enamored with the voice acting like a lot of people seem to be. I can only take hearing "Ember found a scwap of jouwnal" so many times.

116540183.review:
Genuinely one of the most beautiful games I have ever played. The animation was breathtaking. The world even more so. I honestly can't stress enough how worth the time and money I found this game. 

For something that I thought was more innocent and surface level, I was very pleasantly surprised. The game is profound, with a deep message that presents itself through every aspect of its gameplay. 

In the end it really is all about the path, and the hope it takes to keep moving along it even through adversity, even when you're hopeless... even when you feel forlorn. 

All theatrics aside, I genuinely don't want to hype this too much just for you to get your hopes up. I personally think this game was a 20/10, no cap. I'm very easy to please though. That being said, even objectively its minimum a 8/10. The experience was wonderful.

The characters you meet along your journey as well as the dialogue were the most interesting parts personally, the puzzles were really fun and beautifully animated as well. The entire thing is just pleasing to the eye honestly, and to the ears too. The narrator? Her back hurts at this point. The CARRYING she did omfg.

Do take into account that if you are not into puzzle based games then this may not be your cup of tea, since that's literally 80% of the game essentially. However if you don't mind doing puzzles for 5-ish hours then its definitely worth every single penny.

116536487.review:
This game is such a delight. It's a robust little adventure game, with a focus on block-based puzzles with accumulating bells and whistles, and a strong fairy tale vibe. You are an Ember, on a journey to your final destination, the titular "Last Campfire".  The way is not always easy, and several Embers have lost hope and become forlorn.  Your mission, should you choose to accept, is to help those lost Embers by solving short puzzles, which will allow them to move forward.  You in turn will navigate the world to find the Last Campfire, potentially grabbing collectible diary entries of those who came before you.  

The game is pretty straight forward. You'll never get lost, and you don't need to complete all puzzles to move forward (though you will need some).  I used a walkthrough for one puzzle, and to help with locating a collectible (which are not necessary for unlocking all achievements).  The game is universally sweet and welcoming, making it great for playing in quarantine.  It is on the shorter side, but it doesn't outlast it's welcome and it's a great weekend game.

116463592.review:
Finished the game in 4 hours. Not very much impressive, nonetheless, it's a decent and relaxing game with full audio, easy story, simple puzzles and cute characters, no major flaws.

The core is puzzle solving. Players will need to save lost "embers" in each area, each requiring a puzzle to solve. They are basically vibrations of sokoban, throughout the game around 30 of them. One pipe puzzle and one stacking pillar puzzle are well made, took me some time, the rest are easy even for kids. For the first 2 areas player explore on land, mainly using telepathy to move platforms, lure pigs to eat ivy which blocking the way, use mirrors to reflect sun beams... In the 3rd also the last camp player can explore the area by water. The environment varies, though the world is made easily without much details, but it looks fine.

For me 4 hours of gameplay is about the right time. Puzzles feel repeated but not too bad, adding one more area would be painful, though. Devs are good to keep players interested. I encountered 2 bugs, both time stuck at a place but when I quit and re-enter, player position is reset, no game breaking bug or broken file.

I recommend this game for whoever play with a kids, or looking for a relaxing cute puzzle game using fragmented time.

116456923.review: The puzzle range from medium to hard, imo. But it's a very beautiful game, metaphorical, cute, and pretty satisfying.

116440839.review:
The decision to recommend this game (or not) is a tough one. 

First of all, I was surprised about how attached I could get to a little creature barely showing a face. 
Dear me, it's so heart-melting, I wanna give a hug to some of these sad, pondering, scared characters and tell them they're gonna be alright!

What I really liked was the very relaxing atmosphere and soothing music - I fell asleep twice. So this game did something that some more expensive sleeping aid apps couldn't do for me. That's why I give it a thumbs up. 

The puzzles are quite easy to solve, a bit repetetive maybe, but always surrounded by beautiful scenery. 

What really spoiled it for me was the story's end. While the narration allowed for personal interpretation at first, the ending shoves a truckload of pseudo-religious "wisdom" right into your face. And wow, is it depressing! 

So if you are the type of person who radiates so much positive energy that other people feel blinded, if you wake up beaming with joy every morning and are getting tired of your own constant happiness, this game might be your cure. If you want a game to explain to you [spoiler] why ending your own life is the only good decision you will ever be able to make [/spoiler], go for it, but please, don't follow that stupid, stupid advice. If you ever experienced hard times in your life or even tend to have some mental health issues, please stay away from this, or at least, call it out on its prophet of doom glorification, and don't take it serious. After all, it's only a puzzle game.

116387457.review:
This is such a cute little gem filled with colorful sweet graphics and charming music. The story it tells could be summarized by citation [i]the path is important, not the goal[/i]. Our journey isn't always a pleasant one, but we have to keep moving. We can feel sad, afraid or lost, but staying in one place won't help us. We have to move on, search for the light and warmth of a campfire. And even though we can seem to travel alone, we aren't. There is always someone else going in the same direction, don't forget that.

[i]The Last Campfire[/i] is a puzzle game with a difficulty scaling from easy towards challenging. Experienced players shouldn't have any serious problems with it. Younger ones might need a little bit of help though. I have found the puzzles very clever and varied and I have enjoyed even the easy ones. Solving them wasn't anyhow frustrating or tedious, actually I have felt happy and proud of myself (yeah, I have turned 11 again ^^).
Every character in the game you interact with was cute and I enjoyed searching for them all around the island. It was a heartwarming job actually as you are giving them hope back again. There is only one narrator for all of the characters, but it works very well (sounded like a young girl and it reminded me a little bit of a [i]Seed[/i] in [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/366320/Seasons_after_Fall/]Seasons after Fall[/url]). There are little twists to the story that can't surprise the experienced player much and yet the whole story remains very captivating.

The cute graphics, easier puzzle difficulty and the lack of violence may suggest that it's meant for a younger audience. Yes, but sometimes there would arise from the happy look a dark heavy philosophical thoughts that can shake even with a grown up. The tag "emotional" on the store page doesn't lie.

I have truly enjoyed [i]The Last Campfire[/i]. It was a beautiful experience, can only recommend it. <3

116349108.review: The last camp fire is beautifully designed ,with a heart felt storyline we can all relate to. I personally feel it is family friendly while touching on the everyday life struggles whether it be something as simple as solving a puzzle or gripping at your heart with its personal take on finding the light in the darkness. There are a few dark moments between a small morbid joke about pork or the more intense subject of the everyday struggles of depression ,but honestly that is what I enjoyed the most about the game. Though it may be a short game with limited controls the creators have managed to keep it fun and interesting ,while being relatable and leaving you with a sense of accomplishment at the end. 10/10 would recommend <3
